EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One of the worst tornado outbreaks ever recorded in the United States struck the Midwest, Ohio Valley, and Tennessee Valley from the evening hours on December 10 into the morning hours on December 11, 2021. Across Middle Tennessee, a total of 16 tornadoes were determined to have touched down, making this the 5th largest tornado outbreak on record in Middle Tennessee. These tornadoes injured 8 people across Middle Tennessee and caused millions of dollars in property and tree damage in many counties. These tornadoes, combined with the 5 tornadoes that occurred just a few days earlier across Middle Tennessee on December 6, 2021, set a new record for the number of tornadoes during the month of December. In addition, many counties that had tornadoes in December 2021 had never recorded a tornado in the month of December before, including Stewart, Humphreys, Cheatham, Wilson, Trousdale, Overton, Pickett, Coffee, and Grundy Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines were blown down in the Brentwood area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong low pressure system moved north through the Bering Sea and across the Chukotsk Peninsula and Bering Strait December 4th through the 6th. The central pressure of the low dropped to 949 millibars as it moved across the eastern Chukotsk Peninsula the afternoon of December 5th and then weakened as it continued to track north into the Chukchi Sea. A strong weather front associated with this system swept across the West Coast, Interior, and the North Slope of Alaska. This resulted in heavy snow, strong winds, blizzard conditions, and minor coastal flooding at some locations along the Bering Sea coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions and southeast winds gusting from 55 mph to nearly 70 mph occurred across the southern Seward Peninsula. Visibility near zero was observed in Nome, Golovin, and White Mountain. Peak wind gusts reached 58 mph at Nome, 61 mph at Golovin, and 69 mph in White Mountain during the morning hours of December 5th. Businesses and schools were closed across the region due to 5 foot or greater snow drifts and poor visibility. A structure under construction in Golovin had the front paneling ripped off and was flapping in the wind (see image).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Henri made landfall in southwest Rhode Island around noon on August 22nd, then moved slowly northwestward and westward across northern Connecticut and weakened. Henri brought strong wind gusts and flash flooding. The strongest gusts -- to 70 mph -- occurred along the Rhode Island coast. The worst flash flooding occurred in northeast Connecticut.||As the remnants of Henri moved eastward across southern New England on August 23rd, it spawned three tornadoes and a waterspout in MA and also it caused some renewed flooding.||The highest rainfall totals over the two-day period ranged from 5 to 6 inches in Hartford and Tolland Counties in northern Connecticut and in Franklin, Hampshire, and Hampden Counties in western Massachusetts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Bolton, a small, brief tornado touched down, causing minor damage between roughly 175 and 198 Main Street.  One tree was knocked down onto wires and a large branch was ripped from another tree.  It is believed that a funnel cloud initially formed a short distance to the southeast of where the damage was observed, and as it moved northwest, it briefly touched down.  Radar data indicated rotation associated with a shower that moved over the area to be very similar to what was observed with the Marlborough tornado a short while earlier.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the overnight hours on May 17th into the early morning on May 18th, a cluster of slow moving severe thunderstorms associated with a weak mid-level disturbance drifted east across southeastern Louisiana. Ample overnight instability and weak steering flow resulted in damaging wind gusts, flash flooding and a few isolated weak tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highway 75 closed at Waterloo Drive due to high water across the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong east-southeasterly pressure gradient flow between a strong high pressure over the mid-Atlantic and a weak surface low in the northwestern Gulf led to several days of coastal flooding across southeastern Louisiana. Reports varied from each day, with the most impacts during high tide cycles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report from Orleans EOC that Venetian Isles had a few inches of water over roadways and earlier report of water over highways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms which developed across western South Dakota during the evening of June 10 translated eastward through the overnight hours. An increasing low-level jet enhanced shear, with an environment strongly supportive of developing outflow pools with DCAPE of 1500-2000 J/kg. Storms congealed into a linear bowing structure through the late overnight and early morning hours, producing strong to damaging wind gusts as storms moved into southwest Minnesota.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A road weather mesonet station (MN007) near Interstate 90 mile marker 35 northeast of Rushmore measured a thunderstorm wind gust of 58 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A narrow corridor of elevated instability around 1000 J/kg combined with effective shear of 30-35 knots in the exit region of the low-level jet to produce scattered thunderstorms overnight.  A few briefly stronger updrafts produced hail, with isolated reports up to quarter size.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On Wednesday May 19, 2021, an upper level Pacific trough dove south through the Pacific Northwest into the Great Basin and then became nearly stationary for a couple of days. The southerly flow ahead of this system transported middle and upper level moisture into the state, while an upslope east to northeast flow developed at the lower levels in response to relatively strong surface high and low pressure systems respectively set up over Alberta Canada and Utah.  The upslope flow eventually led to cold air damming and the development of a low level barrier jet along the Divide.  This resulted in strong northerly surface winds along eastern slopes adjacent to the Rocky Mountain Front for periods of near blizzard conditions and subsequently sent the unseasonably cold air into the southwestern portion of the state.  Locations from Rogers Pass northward into the East Glacier and Browning areas observed the worst conditions due to the combination of falling snow and gusty northerly winds. The impacts ranged from severe driving conditions on area roadways to isolated power outages. By Thursday morning, the rain began to change to snow at lower elevations over North-central Montana and this transition eventually reached the southwest valleys later that evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 12 inches reported at 9 SSW Havre.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warnings were in effect across much of southern New England with temperatures well up into the 90s and dewpoints in the mid 70s.  Very high CAPE values led to the development of late afternoon and evening severe thunderstorms in portions of western and central Massachusetts and northern Connecticut.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Hartland, a tree and wires were down on South Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warnings were in effect across much of southern New England with temperatures well up into the 90s and dewpoints in the mid 70s.  Very high CAPE values led to the development of late afternoon and evening severe thunderstorms in portions of western and central Massachusetts and northern Connecticut.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On Wednesday May 19, 2021, an upper level Pacific trough dove south through the Pacific Northwest into the Great Basin and then became nearly stationary for a couple of days. The southerly flow ahead of this system transported middle and upper level moisture into the state, while an upslope east to northeast flow developed at the lower levels in response to relatively strong surface high and low pressure systems respectively set up over Alberta Canada and Utah.  The upslope flow eventually led to cold air damming and the development of a low level barrier jet along the Divide.  This resulted in strong northerly surface winds along eastern slopes adjacent to the Rocky Mountain Front for periods of near blizzard conditions and subsequently sent the unseasonably cold air into the southwestern portion of the state.  Locations from Rogers Pass northward into the East Glacier and Browning areas observed the worst conditions due to the combination of falling snow and gusty northerly winds. The impacts ranged from severe driving conditions on area roadways to isolated power outages. By Thursday morning, the rain began to change to snow at lower elevations over North-central Montana and this transition eventually reached the southwest valleys later that evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 10.5 inch snow total was reported at 6 NE Craig.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level closed low moved north through the Northern Rockies into the Canadian Prairies and brought strong westerly winds aloft on the backside of the system. Deep mixing combined with 40 to 50 kt H700 winds were enough to produce a few surface wind gusts at or above 50 kts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Station at 18 E Fort Benton measured a 53 kt  (61 mph) non-thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An active surface trough moved over the territory on the weekend of July 4th. This feature produced widespread impacts of flash flooding, coastal erosion, and landslides.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Talanei newspaper reported extremely high surfs and rip currents that resulted in the  American Samoa Telecommunications Authority (ASTCA) cable break, which left hundreds of Manu'a residents without phone or internet connection for several weeks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An active surface trough moved over the territory on the weekend of July 4th. This feature produced widespread impacts of flash flooding, coastal erosion, and landslides.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds associated with the active trough delayed efforts to restore communication services in Manu'a due to the cable break (see high surf event in Manu'a).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Henri made landfall in southwest Rhode Island around noon on August 22nd, then moved slowly northwestward and westward across northern Connecticut and weakened. Henri brought strong wind gusts and flash flooding. The strongest gusts -- to 70 mph -- occurred along the Rhode Island coast. The worst flash flooding occurred in northeast Connecticut.||As the remnants of Henri moved eastward across southern New England on August 23rd, it spawned three tornadoes and a waterspout in MA and also it caused some renewed flooding.||The highest rainfall totals over the two-day period ranged from 5 to 6 inches in Hartford and Tolland Counties in northern Connecticut and in Franklin, Hampshire, and Hampden Counties in western Massachusetts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Stow, a small, brief tornado touched down, causing minor damage along Great Road (State Highway 117) very near the Stow Police Department Headquarters.  This tornado knocked down a large tree as well as a large branch, which fell across the road.  Similar to the small Bolton tornado, it is believed that a funnel cloud formed to the southeast of the area and then it briefly touched down as it moved northwestward.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous Pacific trough and attendant cold front brought a round of convective precipitation to much of Central and Southwest MT on Friday May, 7, 2021. Mid- level lapse rates exceeded 7 degrees C/km during the afternoon as effective shear briefly approached 50 kts and precipitable water values peaked at around 7 tenths of an inch. These ingredients were enough for a brief period of thunderstorms with severe wind gusts in the Bozeman area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KBZN measured a 50 kt (58 mph) thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An active surface trough moved over the territory on the weekend of July 4th. This feature produced widespread impacts of flash flooding, coastal erosion, and landslides.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During this timeframe, large southerly swells combined with strong winds up to 30 mph caused coastal erosion on the Island of Aunu'u. The seawall was eroded, especially the one near the Assembly of God church.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong and gusty Santa Ana winds once again impacted sections of Ventura and Los Angeles counties. North to northeast wind gusts peaked up to 89 MPH in some spots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very strong and gusty north to northeast winds impacted the Coastal Valleys of Ventura county. Some peak wind reports include: Boney Mountain (gust 78 MPH), Deer Creek (gust 77 MPH), Wiley Ridge (gust 70 MPH), Woolsey Canyon (gust 59 MPH) and Pacific View Drive (gust 60 MPH).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast-moving cold front combined with a potent short-wave trough lifting northeastward across western and northern New England to produce severe thunderstorms across southern New England.  Despite dewpoint temperatures only in the 30s and 40s, the cold pool aloft created instability and there was very strong low-level helicity.  The result was an unprecedented outbreak of tornadoes across Long Island, Connecticut, and Rhode Island.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Marlborough, a tree and power lines were down on Walker Lane at Pettengill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Placeholder...
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was knocked down near the corner of Bethsaida Road and Strawn Road. Time estimated by radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms erupted during the mid to late afternoon hours across north Alabama., with clusters of thunderstorms redeveloping into the early evening hours. Many of the  thunderstorms produced gusty winds of 25 to 35  mph.  However, one thunderstorm produced considerable wind damage between Lexington and Green Hill in Lauderdale County, where several trees and power lines were knocked down, and roofs and outbuildings were damaged. Other trees were knocked down in northeast Alabama.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were knocked down in the vicinity of CR 364 in Green Hill. Power outages were also reported via social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wake low developed on the backside of a cluster of showers and thunderstorms racing south across southeast Louisiana. EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Edgartown at 838 AM EST, Atlantic Drive was closed due to storm surge flooding.  At 847 AM EST, the ASOS at Martha's Vineyard Airpport (KMVY) recorded a gust to 45 mph.  At 921 AM EST, a Weatherflow mesonet site recorded a gust to 46 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Winthrop, Crest Avenue between Revere Street and Grovers Avenue was closed due to coastal flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Substantial monsoon moisture remained over the area as high pressure drifted east over the Plains. As a result, widespread showers and thunderstorms developed with many storms producing heavy rain. This led to several reports of flash flooding and debris flows across portions of west-central and southwest Colorado. Additionally, severe thunderstorms produced large hail and strong winds in Mesa County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail estimated to be the size of quarters accumulated on the road near Skyway on the Grand Mesa. The accumulation was estimated to be 6 inches deep.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained weather spotter estimated 60 mph wind gusts in Palisade.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wake low developed on the backside of a cluster of showers and thunderstorms racing south across southeast Louisiana. This drastically enhanced downdraft winds, producing long duration winds around tropical storm strength across the area with peak gusts as strong as a weak hurricane.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Alexander Street was impassable due to heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary became the focus of a line of strong to severe thunderstorms across the area. This line was long-lived and produced dozens of reports of wind damage, flash flooding and even multiple house fires caused by lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm damaging winds downed a tree on Old Joe Moran Road north of Kiln.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted north through the Mid-South during the day on April 9th. As a result, moist and unstable air pushed into the region ahead of a potent upper-level disturbance approaching from the Central Plains. A couple of lines of severe storms with large hail ignited and pushed across Northeast Arkansas and West Tennessee during the early evening hours. Another line developed across North Mississippi and rolled through later in the evening with damaging winds, large hail, and some flash flooding.

A warm front lifted north into the state Saturday, allowing for an intensification of moisture advection into the area. This was then followed up by a passing cold front and associated cold front, both of which provided lift and helped provide heavy rains across the state. While instability was limited, there was some severe thunderstorms which produced hail during the morning hours of Saturday, March 27th. The main story, however, was the flooding that occurred after the rounds of heavy rain Saturday night into Sunday.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Kentucky Mesonet station just north of Whitley City measured 4.05 inches of rainfall in a 24 hour period.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusted to between 60 and 70 mph for a few hours during the mid to late morning.  At 859 AM EST, a mesonet site at New Shoreham recorded a peak gust to 67 mph.  At 932 AM EST, a mesonet site at the Block Island Jetty recorded a peak wind gust to 69 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Marlborough, a small, brief tornado touched down just west of I-495 near the Marlborough Water Treatment Center. As it traveled to the northwest, it went over a business park and then dissipated just north of Cedar Hill Street.  Several people filmed the tornado and posted it on social media.  Per the NWS survey, several eyewitnesses reported seeing tree branches lofted into the air.  The tornado took down a tree on Cedar Hill Street, which fell on two cars, with damage to one of them.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast-moving cold front combined with a potent short-wave trough lifting northeastward across western and northern New England to produce severe thunderstorms across southern New England.  Despite dewpoint temperatures only in the 30s and 40s, the cold pool aloft created instability and there was very strong low-level helicity.  The result was an unprecedented outbreak of tornadoes across Long Island, Connecticut, and Rhode Island.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Coventry, a tree was down on Phillips Hill Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Windsor Locks at 404 PM EST. the ASOS at Bradley International Airport (KBDL) recorded a gust to 47 knots.  However, the Bradley Weather Contract Observer Supervisor estimated that a gust to 70 knots occurred within one-half mile of the ASOS.  A small brick wall just outside of the Signature building got completely blown down and flattened.  There was also some structural damage to the front of the building.  A small airplane that was parked on the ramp got blown and moved onto the grass.  The top part of their backup rain gauge, the piece which funnels the precipitation into the collection tube, got torn off of the metal can and it blew completely away.  The wind also had picked up something and slammed it into their metal precipitation can, causing a three-inch dent in the can.

The Ironwood observer measured nearly 11 inches during the event, and schools were closed throughout the county on the 6th due to the snow and blowing snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved into the mid-Atlantic late on September 8. Widespread showers and thunderstorms developed in a warm and humid air mass ahead of the front, moving into eastern Pennsylvania during the evening and early overnight hours. With instability waning after dark, much of the convection remained sub-severe. However, some instances of damaging wind did occur, particularly along a bowing line segment in Berks County. Showers and storms continued to gradually weaken as they shifted east later in the night.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One of the worst tornado outbreaks ever recorded in the United States struck the Midwest, Ohio Valley, and Tennessee Valley from the evening hours on December 10 into the morning hours on December 11, 2021. Across Middle Tennessee, a total of 16 tornadoes were determined to have touched down, making this the 5th largest tornado outbreak on record in Middle Tennessee. These tornadoes injured 8 people across Middle Tennessee and caused millions of dollars in property and tree damage in many counties. These tornadoes, combined with the 5 tornadoes that occurred just a few days earlier across Middle Tennessee on December 6, 2021, set a new record for the number of tornadoes during the month of December. In addition, many counties that had tornadoes in December 2021 had never recorded a tornado in the month of December before, including Stewart, Humphreys, Cheatham, Wilson, Trousdale, Overton, Pickett, Coffee, and Grundy Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nashville International Airport ASOS measured a peak wind gust of 78 mph. This is the third highest wind gust ever measured at the airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast-moving cold front combined with a potent short-wave trough lifting northeastward across western and northern New England to produce severe thunderstorms across southern New England.  Despite dewpoint temperatures only in the 30s and 40s, the cold pool aloft created instability and there was very strong low-level helicity.  The result was an unprecedented outbreak of tornadoes across Long Island, Connecticut, and Rhode Island.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Fairhaven, a tree was down on Adams Street between Hope Street and Linden Avenue.

The result was an unprecedented outbreak of tornadoes across Long Island, Connecticut, and Rhode Island.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Raynham, a tree and wires were down on Thrasher Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Persistent flow aloft from the southwest kept an unstable atmosphere in place over the region and allowed multiple severe thunderstorms with large hail to develop over central Montana during the evening and move toward the northeast through the night.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm chaser reported tennis ball size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Persistent flow aloft from the southwest kept an unstable atmosphere in place over the region and allowed multiple severe thunderstorms with large hail to develop over central Montana during the evening and move toward the northeast through the night.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public shared photo, via Facebook, of half dollar size hail near the intersection of Dry Fort Road and Midale Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Persistent flow aloft from the southwest kept an unstable atmosphere in place over the region and allowed multiple severe thunderstorms with large hail to develop over central Montana during the evening and move toward the northeast through the night.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter estimated a 65 mph thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large ridge of high pressure dominated the western United States for several days. This resulted in scorching heat and dry weather across the lower elevations of eastern Utah. Conditions were exceptionally dry which translated to single digit humidity at the surface. Record breaking high temperatures occurred through the period with overnight lows only dropping into the low to mid to upper 60s and 70s in the valleys.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 101 to 106 degrees were reported by various automated weather stations and observers each day through the period. Additionally, overnight lows ranged from 78 to 79 degrees on the morning of the 17th and 18th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited a wildfire 80 miles northwest of Craig.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The West Fire began in mid June due to lightning 80 miles northwest of Craig and grew to 3,429 acres before it was contained in early July.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions worsened slightly across portions of east-central Utah in response to areas of above normal temperatures and below normal precipitation during the month of June. Elsewhere, the drought status remained unchanged through the end of June as a result of the aforementioned conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought remained unchanged through the month of June as exceptional (D4) conditions persisted across all but the northern part of the zone where extreme (D3) conditions continued.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weakly unstable atmosphere with slightly favorable wind shear was able to form some scattered strong thunderstorms, a few a which became severe over isolated portions of northeast Montana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Glendive airport AWOS site (KGDV) recorded a 65 mph thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In a post-cold frontal environment, strong winds from aloft were just barely able to mix down the Little Rocky Mountains of southwest Phillips County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The mesonet site at Zortman measured a 61 mph wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread dense fog blanketed western Kentucky except the extreme westernmost counties during the late night and early morning hours. Visibility was reduced to one-quarter mile or less. The fog formed under a weak ridge of high pressure that extended from the Great Lakes down across the lower Ohio Valley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms developed during the mid afternoon hours in northwest moving into north central Alabama.  A couple of the thunderstorms produced tree damage and small hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A social media report relayed by broadcast media indicated that two trees were knocked down in Anderson. Time estimated by radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large ridge of high pressure dominated the western United States for several days. This resulted in scorching heat and dry weather across the lower elevations of eastern Utah. Conditions were exceptionally dry which translated to single digit humidity at the surface. Record breaking high temperatures occurred through the period with overnight lows only dropping into the low to mid to upper 60s and 70s in the valleys.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 101 to 107 degrees were reported by various automated weather stations each day through the period. Additionally, overnight lows ranged from 74 to 76 degrees on the morning of the 17th and 18th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level shortwave with a modified arctic cold front brought moderate to heavy snow showers across the Cascades, Blues, and Wallowas, with moderate to heavy snow being observed along the Blue Mountain foothills, and in valley locations across the northeast Oregon mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Ski Bluewood ski resort measured 16 inches of new snow over a 24 hour period ending at 0451 PST on Dec. 31st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An abandoned campfire started a wildfire 14 miles southeast of Moab.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pack Creek Fire began in early June due to a campfire that was abandoned 14 miles southeast of Moab and grew to 8,952 acres before it was contained in early July.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited a wildfire 3 miles north-northwest of Sego.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sego Fire began in mid June due to lightning 3 miles north-northwest of Sego and grew to 167 acres before it was contained a week later.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved through the mid-Atlantic on the morning of June 3. Considerable cloud cover lingered during and after the front passage, but breaks of sunshine gradually developed by afternoon. This, combined with a surge of moisture behind the warm front, allowed a moderate amount of instability to develop. A pre-frontal surface trough served as a focus for convective development by late afternoon. Convection became fairly widespread, but the moderate instability combined with only weak to moderate shear limited its overall severity, and the high moisture contributed to a messy convective evolution. A few reports of damaging wind were received, and storms also produced locally heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wires were downed near Somers Point Rd. Time estimated from radar.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Social media and utility reports of downed power lines and numerous power outages in Egg Harbor Twp and its vicinity. Time based on radar and dispatch reports.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front dissipated west of the mid-Atlantic on June 4. However, a lingering surface trough slowly moved through the region. With a lingering warm and moist air mass in place, the surface trough caused convection to develop, starting early in the afternoon. Despite weak wind shear, storms steadily increased in organization, aided by favorable mesoscale interactions. Several storms would go on to pose a threat for damaging winds and hail. Storms eventually coalesced into multiple linear segments which posed a continued wind damage threat. Storms moved offshore by early to mid evening, with a drier air mass behind them.

While several rounds of winter weather occurred leading up to February 15, 2021, the first major winter precipitation event occurred on this day. Light precipitation continued to fall intermittently across the region early in the morning before heavier bands of precipitation fell just prior to daybreak. The precipitation was mainly in the form of heavy sleet for many locations, especially those in western and central Mississippi. However, some parts of the Delta saw an accumulation of snow and sleet while portions of eastern Mississippi experienced freezing rain. Significant accumulations of all winter weather precipitation occurred, some within a short time period. This resulted in significant impact to travel, power outages and disruption to daily life.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mix of sleet and snow fell across the northern part of the county near Dermott. Roads were nearly impassable with stranded cars. Accumulations of up to four and a half inches of snow occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees and wires were downed on Ramah Rd between Boston St and Monroe St. Time estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous wave moving across a moist and unstable airmass produced thunderstorms with large hail over portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer four miles southeast of Harvey measured hail from half-inch to three-quarter-inch in diameter covering the ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous wave moving across a moist and unstable airmass produced thunderstorms with large hail over portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A caller reported quarter-sized hail on Green Garden Road about 3 miles southeast of Harvey.  Time of the report estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous wave moving across a moist and unstable airmass produced thunderstorms with large hail over portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Social media report of one-inch diameter hail at Trenary.  The time of the report was estimated by the radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms caused damage over portions of west and north-central Upper Michigan on the evening of the 28th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report of a tree down along the side of Highway M-28 near Bruce Crossing.  A delayed report with the time estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms caused damage over portions of west and north-central Upper Michigan on the evening of the 28th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a delayed report of trees down along County Road 510, approximately one mile south of the intersection with Red Road.  Time was estimated by radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: West wind gusts reached 58 mph at the Houghton County Airport on the afternoon of the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Houghton County Airport ASOS measured a peak west wind gust of 58 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An advancing cold front, along with shortwave support, created the chance for thunderstorms across the region. Sufficient shear (40kts in the 0-6km layer), moderate to high instability (1500-2000 J/kg of CAPE), and dry mid-level air resulted in damaging winds and hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The State Patrol reported 4 power poles down along SR 209 near mile marker 7.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another round of winter precipitation moved across the region on February 14th. A cold airmass was settling into the region and precipitation fell from the morning through the afternoon. As this precipitation fell, it encountered the cold airmass, with only minor melting. This resulted in some light freezing rain initially before transitioning to mostly sleet across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sleet fell which resulted in icy roads across the county. Accumulations of up to three tenths of an inch occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sleet fell across the region and led to accumulations of up two tenths of an inch across the county. This resulted in icy roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another trough and associated cold front moved across the area and lowered snow levels down to around 2,000 feet. A cold airmass settled into Northwest California in the wake of cold front. Post-frontal showers brought some mountain snow and small hail showers to the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement report of small hail covering Highway 101 in northern Humboldt County around 3:41 a.m. Law enforcement report stated a car accident occurred on the hail covered road. Duration of small hail and exact size unknown, though likely smaller than pea size.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another trough and cold front moved across Northwest California and brought snow levels down to 1,000 to 1,500 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter report of 10 inches of new snow that fell during a 7.5-duration at an elevation of 2,650 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another trough and cold front moved across Northwest California and brought snow levels down to 1,000 to 1,500 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report of 11.5 inches fell during a 24-hour period at an elevation of 2,821 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another trough and cold front moved across Northwest California and brought snow levels down to 1,000 to 1,500 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report of 11 inches of snow fell during a 24-hour duration at an elevation around 2,500 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An advancing cold front, along with shortwave support, created the chance for thunderstorms across the region. Sufficient shear (40kts in the 0-6km layer), moderate to high instability (1500-2000 J/kg of CAPE), and dry mid-level air resulted in damaging winds and hail. Flash flooding occurred, mostly south of Pittsburgh, with training storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel to quarter sized hail reported on social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Major hurricane Ida made landfall as a strong category four hurricane around 11:55am on August 29 near Grand Isle, LA. It then moved very slowly north through south central Louisiana and into Mississippi on August 30. It then turned northeast and moved across the Jackson metro area as a tropical storm and into northeast Mississippi as a tropical depression through the early morning of August 31. Ida brought tropical depression force gusts to portions of southeast Arkansas, which brought down large tree branches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated tropical depression wind gusts of 30-35 miles per hour snapped several large tree branches in Chicot County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Major hurricane Ida made landfall as a strong category four hurricane around 11:55am on August 29 near Grand Isle, LA. It then moved very slowly north through south central Louisiana and into Mississippi on August 30. It then turned northeast and moved across the Jackson metro area as a tropical storm and into northeast Mississippi as a tropical depression through the early morning of August 31. Ida brought tropical storm force gusts to portions of northeast Louisiana, which brought down trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated tropical storm force wind gusts of 40-50 miles per hour resulted in scattered trees and power lines down across the Parish.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Caldor Fire started on August 14th near Little Mountain, CA and south of Pollock Pines in El Dorado County, off Highway 50. The fire started in an area under drought conditions with hot weather and exceptionally dry vegetation in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Caldor Fire was started on August 14th near Little Mountain, CA and south of Pollock Pines in El Dorado County. The fire eventually burned 221,835 acres. The fire made an over-30,000 acre run from August 16th to August 17th. The fire caused evacuations. 81 structures were damaged and 1,003 structures were destroyed, and 5 injuries were reported. The fire was not fully contained in the month of August.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extremely heavy rainfall associated with the remnants of Hurricane Ida overspread southeast New York during the evening of September 1 and continued through the early morning hours of September 2. Rainfall totals ranged from 5-8 inches across much of the region, with much of that rain falling in just a few hours. The ASOS at Central Park recorded 7.19 inches of rain, including 3.15 inches in a single hour between approximately 9:00-10:00pm. This resulted in widespread catastrophic flash flooding across New York City that resulted in extensive road and subway closures and numerous water rescues. Additional rainfall totals from around the region include 7.38 inches at a New York Mesonet station in Fordham in the Bronx, a report of 7.00 inches from a CoCoRaHS observer in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, 6.90 inches from the ASOS at LaGuardia Airport, a spotter report of 6.18 inches in Monroe, a spotter report of 8.09 inches in Scarsdale, and a CoCoRaHS report of 6.72 inches in Locust Valley. Ultimately 17 people died as a result of the flash flooding, including 13 in New York City and 4 in the Lower Hudson Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The body of a man in his 40s was found floating in the Gowanus Canal near 25th Street and Third Avenue in Greenwood Heights, Brooklyn on Thursday, September 2nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another round of winter precipitation moved across the region on February 14th. A cold airmass was settling into the region and precipitation fell from the morning through the afternoon. As this precipitation fell, it encountered the cold airmass, with only minor melting. This resulted in some light freezing rain initially before transitioning to mostly sleet across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy sleet occurred with up to one half of an inch of accumulation in the county. This resulted in icy roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A swift moving cold front brought a brief bout of strong storms to south central Nebraska during the afternoon hours on May 5th. Thunderstorms developed along the cold front from SW to NE, generally along a line from Franklin County to Nance County around 3pm, and moved SE. Most of this activity was fairly weak and poorly organized. However, shortly before 4pm CDT, a stronger storm developed over Clay County and managed to produce nickel size hail and a brief landspout tornado. This became the second event in only a few days where landspout tornadoes were reported in this general area of south central Nebraska. No damage or impacts from the landspout were reported, so it was given an EFU rating. The line of thunderstorms continued SE with no additional severe reports, and exited the area around 6pm CDT.

A stalled frontal boundary became the focus of a line of strong to severe thunderstorms across the area. This line was long-lived and produced dozens of reports of wind damage, flash flooding and even multiple house fires caused by lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm damaging winds downed multiple trees across West Feliciana Parish.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ample moisture remained centered across western Colorado as a shortwave disturbance approached the region. Additionally, residual moisture from previous days convection helped to prime the atmosphere which led to an uptick in shower and thunderstorm coverage. Some storms produced heavy rain which led to localized debris flows across portions of the Pine Gulch Fire burn scar.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A minor debris flow that was approximately 100 feet wide and around 2 inches deep occurred as a result of heavy rain over the northern portion of the Pine Gulch Fire burn area. Radar estimated 0.20 to 0.50 inches of rain fell across the area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An emergency manager reported several trees and power lines down, including in the vicinity of Fair Street and Maysville Pike.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours in a warm and muggy airmass.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree and power line were blown down in Georgetown. The tree fell onto a home at the intersection of Main Street and Catching Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of Wednesday, July 14.  Some of the storms produced damaging winds and numerous tornadoes.  Brief torrential rainfall was also observed with the stronger storm cells.  The areas that were hit hardest were in Buchanan, Delaware, Benton, Linn, and Jones counties in IA, where a total of 14 tornadoes occurred.  7 of the tornadoes had no visible damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Ham Radio operator relayed an estimated thunderstorm wind speed gust of 60 MPH , just west of New Liberty.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Caldor Fire was started on August 14th near Little Mountain, CA and south of Pollock Pines in El Dorado County. The fire eventually burned 221,835 acres. The fire made an over-30,000 acre run from August 16th to August 17th. The fire caused evacuations. 81 structures were damaged and 1,003 structures were destroyed, and 5 injuries were reported. The fire was not fully contained in the month of August.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front dissipated west of the mid-Atlantic on June 4. However, a lingering surface trough slowly moved through the region. With a lingering warm and moist air mass in place, the surface trough caused convection to develop, starting early in the afternoon. Despite weak wind shear, storms steadily increased in organization, aided by favorable mesoscale interactions. Several storms would go on to pose a threat for damaging winds and hail. Storms eventually coalesced into multiple linear segments which posed a continued wind damage threat. Storms moved offshore by early to mid evening, with a drier air mass behind them.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A couple of downed trees and wires were reported in Norristown. Time estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was a multi-round severe weather event. The first round started around 6pm with discrete cells and a few clusters moving from Knox, IN to Hillsdale, MI until around 9pm. The second round featured additional isolated development along a boundary draped across the northern CWA 9P-1A. The third round associated with the primary cold front swept across the CWA 1AM-5AM. ||After further assessment, there appears to be lack of damage for any conclusive tornado event in Coldwater, MI. Most of the severe weather across southern Michigan was in the form of damaging winds, but there was also some large hail on the evening of the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two foot diameter tree branches down in roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an arctic air mass continued to build southward across the South on February 17th, another wave of precipitation overspread this cold air mass across much of Mississippi. The main impacts across central and southern portions of the state were from freezing rain and resulting heavy icing, but some significant accumulations of sleet and snow also occurred in areas mainly north and west of the Natchez Trace. Freezing rain continued through the evening hours, ending from west to east by the early morning of February 18th. Ice accumulated quickly in many locations and downed numerous trees, large limbs, and power lines across the affected areas. Several trees and limbs fell onto power lines, resulting in more widespread power outages as well. Some trees fell onto homes or cars, and significant amounts of ice, sleet, and snow collapsed a few gas station awnings and roofs where accumulations were greatest. In the hardest hit areas, extensive damage to trees and power lines took several months and cost several hundred thousands of dollars to clean up.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sleet began falling late in the morning, with a transition to periods of heavy freezing rain by the early afternoon. Ice accumulations on power lines and in trees across the county was over 0.50 inches by the late evening, with amounts of up to 0.70 inches in some areas. The ice caused widespread broken and downed trees, limbs, and power lines which lead to widespread power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an arctic air mass continued to build southward across the South on February 17th, another wave of precipitation overspread this cold air mass across much of Mississippi. The main impacts across central and southern portions of the state were from freezing rain and resulting heavy icing, but some significant accumulations of sleet and snow also occurred in areas mainly north and west of the Natchez Trace. Freezing rain continued through the evening hours, ending from west to east by the early morning of February 18th. Ice accumulated quickly in many locations and downed numerous trees, large limbs, and power lines across the affected areas. Several trees and limbs fell onto power lines, resulting in more widespread power outages as well. Some trees fell onto homes or cars, and significant amounts of ice, sleet, and snow collapsed a few gas station awnings and roofs where accumulations were greatest. In the hardest hit areas, extensive damage to trees and power lines took several months and cost several hundred thousands of dollars to clean up.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of sleet during the morning and early afternoon brought new accumulations of up to around 1 inch of sleet to the county, with a transition to freezing rain during the afternoon producing around 0.25 inches of ice on trees and power lines by the evening. Some light freezing drizzle continued into the overnight hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an arctic air mass continued to build southward across the South on February 17th, another wave of precipitation overspread this cold air mass across northeast Louisiana. The main impacts across this portion of the state were from freezing rain and resulting heavy icing, but some significant accumulations of sleet and snow also occurred. Freezing rain continued through the evening hours. Ice accumulated quickly in many locations and downed numerous trees, large limbs, and power lines. Several trees and limbs fell onto power lines, resulting in more widespread power outages as well. Significant impacts to travel and electrical infrastructure occurred in the hardest hit areas. In the Vidalia area, heavy rain flooded several roads due to ice-blocked drainages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 0.5 inches of sleet fell across the parish early in the day, transitioning to freezing rain during the afternoon. Accumulations of around 0.50 inches of ice downed trees and power lines and caused widespread power outages across the parish.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an arctic air mass continued to build southward across the South on February 17th, another wave of precipitation overspread this cold air mass across northeast Louisiana. The main impacts across this portion of the state were from freezing rain and resulting heavy icing, but some significant accumulations of sleet and snow also occurred. Freezing rain continued through the evening hours. Ice accumulated quickly in many locations and downed numerous trees, large limbs, and power lines. Several trees and limbs fell onto power lines, resulting in more widespread power outages as well. Significant impacts to travel and electrical infrastructure occurred in the hardest hit areas. In the Vidalia area, heavy rain flooded several roads due to ice-blocked drainages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several streets in Vidalia were flooded over by runoff from heavy rain and ice jammed drainages across town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated to scattered thunderstorms developed over portions of the I-25 corridor in El Paso and Pueblo Counties during the afternoon, and then spread eastward to southeastward across the Highway 50 corridor through the evening. Some of the thunderstorms were strong to severe, with the more intense storms producing large hail of 1-2 inches in diameter and damaging wind gusts of 60-70 mph. Additionally, a tornado and wind gusts up to around 90 mph were observed across the eastern plains on this day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power poles are down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm and unstable air in advance of a cold front and mid-level shortwave along with a sea breeze interacting with convective outflow boundaries led to severe thunderstorms across southeast South Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management and social media indicated several businesses along Market Street flooded with 8 to 16 inches of standing water inside buildings. Additionally, rainfall amounts around 3.5 inches resulted in the following streets, intersections, and areas in downtown Charleston to be closed due to flooding: Calhoun Street between Rutledge Avenue and Smith Street, Chisolm Street between Broad Street and Tradd Street, Colonial Street between Broad Street and Tradd Street, Hagood Avenue at Fishburne Street, King Street at Huger Street, Market Street between Meeting Street and East Bay Street, Romney Street at North Nassau Street, Smith Street at Marion Street, Tradd Street between Chisholm Street and East Bay Street, the Crosstown Expressway between Coming Street and Norman Street, Washington Street and Concord Street between Laurens Street and Queens Street, the Harleston Village area and the White Point Gardens area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lifting warm front across the region brought a hot and humid air mass into the region, leading to maximum heat indices reaching 95 to 98 degrees across some valley locations of eastern New York.||An approaching cold front from the west led to numerous showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening hours. Some of these storms became severe with several reports of downed trees and power lines. A couple trees fell onto homes with another falling onto a camper trailer. No injuries were reported. A funnel cloud was spotted by an observer in Warren County looking northward toward Lake George. A lightning strike hit a structure near Galway, causing a fire. Sporadic power outages occurred as a result of these storms with more than 1,000 National Grid customers without power in Washington County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees and wires were downed near the Town of New Paltz.

The main impacts across central and southern portions of the state were from freezing rain and resulting heavy icing, but some significant accumulations of sleet and snow also occurred in areas mainly north and west of the Natchez Trace. Freezing rain continued through the evening hours, ending from west to east by the early morning of February 18th. Ice accumulated quickly in many locations and downed numerous trees, large limbs, and power lines across the affected areas. Several trees and limbs fell onto power lines, resulting in more widespread power outages as well. Some trees fell onto homes or cars, and significant amounts of ice, sleet, and snow collapsed a few gas station awnings and roofs where accumulations were greatest. In the hardest hit areas, extensive damage to trees and power lines took several months and cost several hundred thousands of dollars to clean up.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several pictures and reports on social media from across the county showed large branches and a few trees downed by around 0.25 inches of accumulated ice.  Some power outages occurred in parts of the county.

CZ_NAME: EDISTO BEACH SC TO SAVANNAH GA OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong moisture convergence across the Tri-County Area and a pinned sea breeze circulation led to thunderstorms developing during peak heating hours. A few thunderstorms eventually drifted over nearby coastal waters late afternoon, producing strong wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Weatherflow site at Calibogue Sound measured a wind gust of 37 knots.

CZ_NAME: S SANTEE R TO EDISTO BEACH SC OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The interaction of a cold front arriving from the west and a sea breeze circulation within a warm and moist environment led to severe thunderstorms that eventually shifted across coastal waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Weatherflow site at Folly South End measured a peak wind gust of 40 knots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was a multi-round severe weather event. The first round started around 6pm with discrete cells and a few clusters moving from Knox, IN to Hillsdale, MI until around 9pm. The second round featured additional isolated development along a boundary draped across the northern CWA 9P-1A. The third round associated with the primary cold front swept across the CWA 1AM-5AM. ||After further assessment, there appears to be lack of damage for any conclusive tornado event in Coldwater, MI. Most of the severe weather across southern Michigan was in the form of damaging winds, but there was also some large hail on the evening of the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: WSBT relayed via Twitter a picture of a few broken tree branches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An advancing cold front, along with shortwave support, created the chance for thunderstorms across the region. Sufficient shear (40kts in the 0-6km layer), moderate to high instability (1500-2000 J/kg of CAPE), and dry mid-level air resulted in damaging winds and hail. Flash flooding occurred, mostly south of Pittsburgh, with training storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Slightly smaller than quarter sized hail was reported on social media.

CZ_NAME: SAVANNAH GA TO ALTAMAHA SD GA OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak shortwave passing across the region along the edge of a broad trough extending across much of the eastern United States led to a few thunderstorms capable of producing strong winds across local coastal waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Weatherflow sensor on the south end of Tybee Island measured a wind gust of 35 knots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with large hail spread northward across East Tennessee during the early morning hours of March 27, reaching southwest Virginia by late morning. These storms were associated with a warm front, which later stalled across northeast Tennessee. This stalled front was the focus of additional thunderstorms that produced damaging wind gusts and flooding in the evening of March 27 and into March 28.
The interaction of a cold front arriving from the west and a sea breeze circulation within a warm and moist environment led to severe thunderstorms that eventually shifted across coastal waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Shutes Folly Weatherflow sensor measured a peak wind gust of 40 knots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The interaction of a cold front arriving from the west and a sea breeze circulation within a warm and moist environment led to severe thunderstorms that eventually shifted across coastal waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lifting warm front across the region brought a hot and humid air mass into the region, leading to maximum heat indices reaching 95 to 98 degrees across some valley locations of eastern New York.||An approaching cold front from the west led to numerous showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening hours. Some of these storms became severe with several reports of downed trees and power lines. A couple trees fell onto homes with another falling onto a camper trailer. No injuries were reported. A funnel cloud was spotted by an observer in Warren County looking northward toward Lake George. A lightning strike hit a structure near Galway, causing a fire. Sporadic power outages occurred as a result of these storms with more than 1,000 National Grid customers without power in Washington County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several impassable roadways, downed trees and phone lines and power outages were reported around the Moffitt Beach State Campground in the Town of Lake Pleasant. One  of the trees fell onto a camper trailer.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slowly moving storm system brought several rounds of showers and thunderstorms to eastern Iowa, northwest Illinois and far northeast Missouri during the day on Wednesday April 7, 2021. The heavy rainfall occurred south of a Fairfield to Galesburg line with reports ranging from 1.13 inches in Burlington to 1.80 inches in Bushnell Illinois. A few of these thunderstorms became severe and produced damaging winds in McDonough, Henderson, and Hancock Counties during the late afternoon and early evening hours. Damage was also reported to some mobile homes and a garage on the southwest side of Cedar Rapids due to a weak tornado that caused one minor injury.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported thunderstorm wind damage to a farm outbuilding south of Aledo. Pictures via social media show part of a wall blown out,  but the barn was open to one side and the other wall is partially covered. Time of the event was estimated using radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an arctic air mass continued to build southward across the South on February 17th, another wave of precipitation overspread this cold air mass across southeastern Arkansas. Some freezing rain also fell with significant accumulations of sleet and snow in far southeast Arkansas. The freezing and frozen precipitation impacted travel across the region, and in Crossett the accumulations of ice, sleet, and snow collapsed a roof at a bowling alley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mix of wintry precipitation fell across Ashley County. Up to 2 inches of heavy snow fell in parts of the county, including up to 0.75 inches of sleet mixed in with the snow in other parts of the county. By the evening of the 17th, the combined weight of sleet and snow collapsed the roof of Max Bowl in Crossett.

Some freezing rain also fell with significant accumulations of sleet and snow in far southeast Arkansas. The freezing and frozen precipitation impacted travel across the region, and in Crossett the accumulations of ice, sleet, and snow collapsed a roof at a bowling alley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mix of wintry precipitation fell across Chicot County. An early mix of 1 to 2 inches of snow and sleet fell in parts of the county, with a transition to freezing rain accumulating to near 0.25 inches by the afternoon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe storms moved across the state on April 7th and again on April 9th and 10th associated with the passage two cold fronts. Large hail and damaging winds were the main impacts noted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Another tree was blown down on a house in East Camden.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm produced non-severe hail in Dallas county at Sparkman.

A cold front from Canada surged into the region during the morning of April 20, and was over the southern counties by the late afternoon. Ahead of the front at 400 pm CDT, it was 76 degrees at Monticello (Drew County) with plenty of sunshine. It was a different world behind the front, with 33 degrees at Harrison (Boone County). The transition from mild to cold resulted in windy conditions. Winds shifted to the northwest at 10 to 20 mph, with maximum gusts between 30 and 40 mph in places.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow in the amount of 0.9 inches was measured on an elevated surface.

Late season snow event with a strong Arctic front that pushed through the CWA with an upper level trough extending across the northern half of southwestern Kansas.  Snow amounts ranged from 1-7 inches, more farther north along the Hwy 96 and I-70 corridors. Winter weather advisories were issued for much of the area to include the highest amounts recorded.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven inches of snow was measured on the south side of Hays.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With slick roads causing accidents across the Kansas City Metro one such accident proved fatal, just on the Missouri side of the Missouri River along I-635 near where it intersects with Horizons Parkway. Icy roads have not been determined officially as the cause, but with icy roads that day it's strongly plausible as a contributor to the accident.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An accident along I-635 just north of the Missouri River was fatal for one motorist. Icy roads have not been determined officially as the cause, but with 2 to 4 inches of snow on the roads causing slick conditions that morning it's strongly plausible as a contributor to the accident. A vehicle was travelling south along I-635 and crashed head on into a semi. This took place south of Horizons Parkway along I-635, but north of the Missouri River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front approached the mid-Atlantic coast on April 21. Ahead of the front, modest instability developed in a strongly sheared and strongly forced environment. This led to the development of convection along and ahead of the front as it moved through during the mid afternoon hours. Mixed modes of linear and discrete storm cells were present, some of which became strong to severe. Scattered instances of hail and wind damage were reported across much of the eastern mid-Atlantic.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Time of report estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front approached the mid-Atlantic coast on April 21. Ahead of the front, modest instability developed in a strongly sheared and strongly forced environment. This led to the development of convection along and ahead of the front as it moved through during the mid afternoon hours. Mixed modes of linear and discrete storm cells were present, some of which became strong to severe. Scattered instances of hail and wind damage were reported across much of the eastern mid-Atlantic.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured by personal weather station kdeselby13.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Major hurricane Ida made landfall as a strong category four hurricane around 11:55am on August 29 near Grand Isle, LA. It then moved very slowly north through south central Louisiana and into Mississippi on August 30. It then turned northeast and moved across the Jackson metro area as a tropical storm and into northeast Mississippi as a tropical depression through the early morning of August 31. Ida brought tropical storm force gusts to portions of Mississippi, which brought down trees and power lines. Rainfall amounts of 4-8 inches occurred, which resulted in localized flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tropical storm force wind gusts resulted in several trees and power lines downed across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an arctic air mass continued to build southward across the South on February 17th, another wave of precipitation overspread this cold air mass across much of Mississippi. The main impacts across central and southern portions of the state were from freezing rain and resulting heavy icing, but some significant accumulations of sleet and snow also occurred in areas mainly north and west of the Natchez Trace. Freezing rain continued through the evening hours, ending from west to east by the early morning of February 18th. Ice accumulated quickly in many locations and downed numerous trees, large limbs, and power lines across the affected areas. Several trees and limbs fell onto power lines, resulting in more widespread power outages as well. Some trees fell onto homes or cars, and significant amounts of ice, sleet, and snow collapsed a few gas station awnings and roofs where accumulations were greatest. In the hardest hit areas, extensive damage to trees and power lines took several months and cost several hundred thousands of dollars to clean up.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An early mix of sleet and freezing rain brought around 0.25 inches of new sleet and light ice accumulations on trees and elevated surfaces. Then heavier freezing rain during the afternoon caused rapid accumulations of ice on trees, power lines, and roads in the county. By the afternoon roads were very hazardous, and a combination of ice and rain even led to some flooded roads and highways. Total ice accumulations through the evening were around 0.35 inches across much of the county, but amounts of up to 0.50 inches were reported in some locations. Downed trees and power lines were widespread across the county, and the weight of ice also collapsed several carports and patio awnings. Some roads had up to 3 inches of sleet and slush combined from the current and previous winter storms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary brought waves of heavy rainfall to central Kentucky from February 26 through February 28. This caused record rainfall, isolated severe winds, and even a tornado. As a result, Bowling Green set a February daily rainfall record with 5.11 on the 28th. The severe winds brought down some trees and a power pole, but the most property damage came from a brief EF1 tornado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was flooding on Gray Gap Road at Turner Branch Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an arctic air mass continued to build southward across the South on February 17th, another wave of precipitation overspread this cold air mass across northeast Louisiana. The main impacts across this portion of the state were from freezing rain and resulting heavy icing, but some significant accumulations of sleet and snow also occurred. Freezing rain continued through the evening hours. Ice accumulated quickly in many locations and downed numerous trees, large limbs, and power lines. Several trees and limbs fell onto power lines, resulting in more widespread power outages as well. Significant impacts to travel and electrical infrastructure occurred in the hardest hit areas. In the Vidalia area, heavy rain flooded several roads due to ice-blocked drainages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to around 0.40 inches of ice accumulated across the parish, and power outages were common across the parish due to downed trees and power lines. Heavy rain and icing of roofs and in gutters caused water problems for houses in the Vidalia area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed over the interior mountains of northwest California during late July. A hot deeply mixed airmass promoted isolated instances of strong gusty winds the resulted in tree damage in the vicinity of Weaverville.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind damage 3 miles south of Weaverville. Roads were blocked due to tree damage. Power was out as well. Measured gust from RAWS station was 43 mph. City property was also damaged due to wind driven hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moist southerly flow and daytime heating ahead of a strong trough combined with sufficient wind shear to bring a line of severe storms through the region. Within this line, a few tornadoes and some wind damage occurred across Louisiana and Arkansas and the Delta of Mississippi.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two power poles and a tree were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slowly moving storm system brought several rounds of showers and thunderstorms to eastern Iowa, northwest Illinois and far northeast Missouri during the day on Wednesday April 7, 2021. The heavy rainfall occurred south of a Fairfield to Galesburg line with reports ranging from 1.13 inches in Burlington to 1.80 inches in Bushnell Illinois. A few of these thunderstorms became severe and produced damaging winds in McDonough, Henderson, and Hancock Counties during the late afternoon and early evening hours. Damage was also reported to some mobile homes and a garage on the southwest side of Cedar Rapids due to a weak tornado that caused one minor injury.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local broadcast media reported 4 inch diameter tree branches blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant winter/ice storm struck eastern Kentucky from February 14th to 16th 2021. Ice accumulations from freezing rain ranged from 0.25 inches to as much as 0.75 inches by the the time the storm had ended. Sleet accumulations of 0.3 to as much as 2 inches also occurred. The weight of the ice brought down tree limbs, entire trees, power lines, and power poles all across eastern Kentucky. The highest ice accumulations occurred primarily along the higher ridges around eastern Kentucky with much lower amounts in the surrounding valleys. During the height of the icing event, many roads around eastern Kentucky were impassable or nearly so. Many power outages resulted from downed power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A little over three tenths of an inch of ice accumulation due to freezing rain occurred in and around Inez. The weight of the ice brought down trees and power lines around the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions worsened slightly across portions of west-central Colorado in response to areas of above normal temperatures and below normal precipitation during the month of June. Conditions improved slightly across portions of southwest Colorado. Elsewhere, the drought status remained unchanged through the end of June as a result of the aforementioned conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought remained largely unchanged across the forecast area during the month of June. Extreme (D3) conditions persisted across the western portion of the zone and expanded slightly to the northeast. Meanwhile, severe (D2) drought continued over the central and northeast portions while the moderate (D1) category lingered over the southeast areas. As a result of the ongoing drought, the town of Norwood is down to less than 17% drinking water left and ranchers are selling off cattle as there is not enough hay to keep the numbers up.

CZ_NAME: FOUR CORNERS / UPPER DOLORES RIVER BASIN
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions worsened slightly across portions of west-central Colorado in response to areas of above normal temperatures and below normal precipitation during the month of June. Conditions improved slightly across portions of southwest Colorado. Elsewhere, the drought status remained unchanged through the end of June as a result of the aforementioned conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought remained unchanged through the month of June. Exceptional (D4) conditions persisted across the far southern portion of the zone while the extreme (D3) category continued elsewhere. As a result of the ongoing drought, ranchers in Montezuma County are selling off cattle as there is not enough hay to keep the numbers up.

The extreme (D3) drought persisted across the central portion of the zone with a small sliver of severe (D2) conditions over the far east-central portion of the zone through the end of June.

Conditions improved slightly across portions of southwest Colorado. Elsewhere, the drought status remained unchanged through the end of June as a result of the aforementioned conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Recycled moisture underneath a ridge of high pressure was enough to fuel isolated to scattered showers across western Colorado. As these showers decayed they produced gusty outflow winds with some gusts meeting high wind criteria in Mesa County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A peak wind gust of 60 MPH was measured by the automated weather station at the Grand Junction Regional Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions worsened slightly across portions of west-central Colorado in response to areas of above normal temperatures and below normal precipitation during the month of June. Conditions improved slightly across portions of southwest Colorado. Elsewhere, the drought status remained unchanged through the end of June as a result of the aforementioned conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought remained unchanged through the month of June. Exceptional (D4) drought conditions persisted across the southwest portion of the zone while the extreme (D3) drought remained in the central portion of the zone through the end of the month. The severe (D2) category remained across the far northeast portion of the zone through the end of June.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions worsened slightly across portions of west-central Colorado in response to areas of above normal temperatures and below normal precipitation during the month of June. Conditions improved slightly across portions of southwest Colorado. Elsewhere, the drought status remained unchanged through the end of June as a result of the aforementioned conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought remained unchanged across the zone through the month of June as extreme (D3) conditions persisted across the western and central areas. The severe (D2) drought remained across some of the eastern portion of the zone with moderate (D1) conditions over the far northeast portion.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions worsened slightly across portions of west-central Colorado in response to areas of above normal temperatures and below normal precipitation during the month of June. Conditions improved slightly across portions of southwest Colorado. Elsewhere, the drought status remained unchanged through the end of June as a result of the aforementioned conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought remained unchanged through the month of June. Exceptional (D4) conditions persisted across the southern portion of the zone as the extreme (D3) category continued up north.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front approached the mid-Atlantic coast on April 21. Ahead of the front, modest instability developed in a strongly sheared and strongly forced environment. This led to the development of convection along and ahead of the front as it moved through during the mid afternoon hours. Mixed modes of linear and discrete storm cells were present, some of which became strong to severe. Scattered instances of hail and wind damage were reported across much of the eastern mid-Atlantic.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed onto an unoccupied vehicle.

Late season snow event with a strong Arctic front that pushed through the CWA with an upper level trough extending across the northern half of southwestern Kansas.  Snow amounts ranged from 1-7 inches, more farther north along the Hwy 96 and I-70 corridors. Winter weather advisories were issued for much of the area to include the highest amounts recorded.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 4.0 inches was observed at a location 3 WSW Hanston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an arctic air mass continued to build southward across the South on February 17th, another wave of precipitation overspread this cold air mass across northeast Louisiana. The main impacts across this portion of the state were from freezing rain and resulting heavy icing, but some significant accumulations of sleet and snow also occurred. Freezing rain continued through the evening hours. Ice accumulated quickly in many locations and downed numerous trees, large limbs, and power lines. Several trees and limbs fell onto power lines, resulting in more widespread power outages as well. Significant impacts to travel and electrical infrastructure occurred in the hardest hit areas. In the Vidalia area, heavy rain flooded several roads due to ice-blocked drainages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light fell across northern parts of the parish during the morning, but freezing rain became the concern during the afternoon. Up to around 0.25 inches of ice accumulated across the parish, and widespread power outages occurred due to fallen trees, limbs, and power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an arctic air mass continued to build southward across the South on February 17th, another wave of precipitation overspread this cold air mass across northeast Louisiana. The main impacts across this portion of the state were from freezing rain and resulting heavy icing, but some significant accumulations of sleet and snow also occurred. Freezing rain continued through the evening hours. Ice accumulated quickly in many locations and downed numerous trees, large limbs, and power lines. Several trees and limbs fell onto power lines, resulting in more widespread power outages as well. Significant impacts to travel and electrical infrastructure occurred in the hardest hit areas. In the Vidalia area, heavy rain flooded several roads due to ice-blocked drainages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A light mix of wintry precipitation in the morning transitioned to freezing rain by the afternoon. Amounts of between 0.25 to 0.50 inches of ice accumulation were common across the parish, and numerous downed trees and power lines caused widespread power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shallow cold airmass was in place across the region. Light precipitation that fell over this cold airmass resulted in light freezing rain on the evening of February 12th into the early morning hours of February 13th. Some accumulation occurred on bridges and overpasses.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light freezing rain resulted in icing on bridges and roadways in the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An advancing cold front, along with shortwave support, created the chance for thunderstorms across the region. Sufficient shear (40kts in the 0-6km layer), moderate to high instability (1500-2000 J/kg of CAPE), and dry mid-level air resulted in damaging winds and hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel to quarter sized hail was reported by the public.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited a wildfire 80 miles northwest of Craig.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The West Fire began in mid June due to lightning 80 miles northwest of Craig and grew to 3,429 acres before it was contained in early July.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike most likely ignited a wildfire 26 miles northeast of Bonanza.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Snake John Fire began in early July, most likely due to lightning, 26 miles northeast of Bonanza and grew to 655 acres before it was contained a couple of days later.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large ridge of high pressure dominated the western United States for several days. This resulted in scorching heat and dry weather across the lower elevations of eastern Utah. Conditions were exceptionally dry which translated to single digit humidity at the surface. Record breaking high temperatures occurred through the period with overnight lows only dropping into the low to mid to upper 60s and 70s in the valleys.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 95 to 102 degrees were reported by various automated weather stations each day through the period. Additionally, overnight lows ranged from 65 to 67 degrees on the morning of the 8th, 9th and 10th.
