EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A triple point set up across the eastern half of the CWA with the surface low moving along northern counties with a cold front draped to the southwest and dryline to the south.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Recorded in Elkhart.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain brought flooding to portions of eastern Centre and Northeast Mifflin county on September 23rd.  ||The National Weather Service State College reported that the area around Aaronsburg, Spring Mills, and Alfarata in eastern Centre and northeastern Mifflin Counties received between 5-5.50 inches of rain.||Flooding and road closures were reported in State College, Bellefonte, Park Forest Village, Woodward, Boalsburg, Pleasant Gap, Stormstown, Lemont, Zion, Belleville, Houserville, Mill Hall, Pine Grove Mills, Milesburg, and Coburn and on Elk Creek and Penns Creek.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall brought flooding around the Penns and Elk Creek areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A chain dragging from a moving vehicle ignited a wildfire near Purdy Mesa Reservoir in Mesa County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lands End 2 Fire began on July 8th near Purdy Mesa Reservoir as a result of a chain dragging from a moving vehicle. The fire quickly grew to 120 acres before being contained later that evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed near a cold front across southeast South Dakota during the evening. With MUCAPE around 1000 J/kg and decent deep-layer wind shear focused near the boundary, a few storms organized into loose clusters with bowing structures.
A short-duration bow echo evolved from thunderstorms which developed on the warm side of a stationary frontal boundary in the presence of weak shear and strong DCAPE.

A large ridge of high pressure dominated the western United States for several days. This resulted in scorching heat and dry weather across the lower elevations of eastern Utah. Conditions were exceptionally dry which translated to single digit humidity at the surface. Record breaking high temperatures occurred through the period with overnight lows only dropping into the low to mid to upper 60s and 70s in the valleys.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 102 to 109 degrees were reported by various automated weather stations each day through the period. Additionally, overnight lows ranged from 71 to 77 degrees on the morning of the 8th and 9th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large ridge of high pressure dominated the western United States for several days. This resulted in scorching heat and dry weather across the lower elevations of eastern Utah. Conditions were exceptionally dry which translated to single digit humidity at the surface. Record breaking high temperatures occurred through the period with overnight lows only dropping into the low to mid to upper 60s and 70s in the valleys.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 101 to 107 degrees were reported by the Cooperative Observers across Canyonlands National Park each day through the period. Additionally, overnight lows ranged from 70 to 73 degrees on the morning of the 8th, 9th and 10th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the daytime hours on March 23rd thru the early morning hours on March 24th, a deep west coast trough helped to deliver progressive yet strong southwesterly upper-level to mid-level moist flow across the northern Gulf coast. At the surface, several waves of strong to severe thunderstorms approached the area from the west, quickly advancing east causing widespread severe thunderstorms across coastal waters from the afternoon on March 23rd through the early morning hours on March 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet Station KXYU Bayou Bienvenue (Vertical Lift) measured a peak wind gust of 39 mph or 34 knots from thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A narrow zone of enhanced instability developed ahead of a cold front with up to 1500-2000 J/kg MLCAPE.  As a mid-level jet streak crossed the boundary in the late afternoon and evening, deep layer shear increased to around 50 knots. Isolated thunderstorms developed supercell characteristics, resulting in large hail and damaging wind.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County Emergency Manager estimated wind gusts as high as 80 to 90 mph.

A large outflow boundary from a late night convective complex across northeast South Dakota and west central MN pushed southward, and interacted with a strong low-level jet. With steep mid-level lapse rates present, convective initiation resulted in intense updrafts along the boundary which produced large hail.

Thunderstorms with large hail spread northward across East Tennessee during the early morning hours of March 27, reaching southwest Virginia by late morning. These storms were associated with a warm front, which later stalled across northeast Tennessee. This stalled front was the focus of additional thunderstorms that produced damaging wind gusts and flooding in the evening of March 27 and into March 28.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roadways across Sullivan County were flooded or impassable, including Timbertree Branch Road, Childers Ferry Road, and Princeton Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged monsoon pattern persisted across much of the region the last couple of weeks of July. This led to cooler and unsettled conditions and brought some much needed precipitation to the Western Slope. As a result, drought conditions improved by one or more categories across many zones by the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions improved across some of the zone during the month of July. Exceptional (D4) drought over the southern tier of the zone improved to the extreme (D3) category as well as over the north-central portion of the zone. The exceptional drought continued over the central portion of the zone and expanded to include the far northeast corner. The extreme drought that was in place over the northwest portion of the zone at the beginning of July remained unchanged.

This stalled front was the focus of additional thunderstorms that produced damaging wind gusts and flooding in the evening of March 27 and into March 28.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding on Highway 58 south of Kingston, and at Gordon Hollow Road.

Amidst a prolonged wet and soggy period, another round of heavy rainfall over central Georgia triggered isolated flash flooding through the day on September 20th. Though much of the flooding occurred during the first half of the day, another localized report of flash flooding was reported late in the evening with another round of shower activity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were several social media reports of flooding of the Eastman Walmart Parking lot. Radar estimates indicate that between 4 and 5 inches of rain had fallen over the area in a short period of time, resulting in the flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Amidst a prolonged wet and soggy period, another round of heavy rainfall over central Georgia triggered isolated flash flooding through the day on September 20th. Though much of the flooding occurred during the first half of the day, another localized report of flash flooding was reported late in the evening with another round of shower activity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Emergency Manager reported water over the roadway on Cochran Highway near Hawkinsville. Radar estimates indicate that between 1.5 and 3 inches of rain had fallen over the area in a short period of time, resulting in the flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Amidst a prolonged wet and soggy period, another round of heavy rainfall over central Georgia triggered isolated flash flooding through the day on September 20th. Though much of the flooding occurred during the first half of the day, another localized report of flash flooding was reported late in the evening with another round of shower activity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Emergency Manager reported water over the roadway on I-16 near the Bleckley/Laurens county line. Radar estimates indicate that between 2 and 3 inches of rain had fallen over the area in a short period of time, resulting in the flash flooding.

CZ_NAME: PARADOX VALLEY / LOWER DOLORES RIVER BASIN
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged monsoon pattern persisted across much of the region the last couple of weeks of July. This led to cooler and unsettled conditions and brought some much needed precipitation to the Western Slope. As a result, drought conditions improved by one or more categories across many zones by the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought improved across the entirety of the zone through the month of July. The exceptional (D4) drought across all but the far southern portion of the zone improved to the severe (D2) category. An exception was the far northwest portion of the zone which improved to the extreme (D3) category. The extreme drought that was present at the beginning of July over the far southern portion of the zone improved to the severe category.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged monsoon pattern persisted across much of the region the last couple of weeks of July. This led to cooler and unsettled conditions and brought some much needed precipitation to the Western Slope. As a result, drought conditions improved by one or more categories across many zones by the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought improved across some of the zone through the month of July. The severe (D2) drought improved to the abnormally dry to moderate (D0 to D1) category over the eastern portion of the zone. Meanwhile, the extreme (D3) drought continued over the far northwest portion of the zone with the severe drought persisting elsewhere.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with large hail spread northward across East Tennessee during the early morning hours of March 27, reaching southwest Virginia by late morning. These storms were associated with a warm front, which later stalled across northeast Tennessee. This stalled front was the focus of additional thunderstorms that produced damaging wind gusts and flooding in the evening of March 27 and into March 28.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding of Beaver Creek was ongoing in the Bristol Motor Speedway parking lots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved slowly across southwest Virginia ahead of a cold front that swept in from the Ohio Valley later in the morning. Early morning heavy rainfall over eastern Kentucky clipped Wise County Virginia as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water across several roads near the towns of Big Stone Gap and Pound.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major weather system that brought damaging thunderstorms and flooding rainfall to the Tennessee Valley also had impacts, although lesser, in southwestern North Carolina. The ground was already near saturation due to heavy rains from a few days earlier.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Streams were out of their banks and flooding yards.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat and humidity led to strong instability by afternoon, as a weak frontal boundary settled into southeast South Dakota. Strong instability but weak deep-layer shear resulted in brief, intense and generally outflow-dominant storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several tree limbs up to six inches in diameter were broken by wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat and humidity led to strong instability by afternoon, as a weak frontal boundary settled into southeast South Dakota. Strong instability but weak deep-layer shear resulted in brief, intense and generally outflow-dominant storms.
An isolated thunderstorm within an environment with a well-defined inverted-V sounding produced a downburst wind gust.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gust was measured by South Dakota RWIS near Cavour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong thunderstorm developed along a frontal boundary in the presence of 40 knots of deep-layer shear, which resulted in a briefly rotating storm producing marginally large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail was mostly pea size, but there were a few stones up to ping-pong ball size.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong thunderstorm developed along a frontal boundary in the presence of 40 knots of deep-layer shear, which resulted in a briefly rotating storm producing marginally large hail.
A strong thunderstorm developed along a frontal boundary in the presence of 40 knots of deep-layer shear, which resulted in a briefly rotating storm producing marginally large hail.
Clusters of thunderstorms developed along an advancing cold front, some of which produced small hail and sub-severe wind gusts.

Within a cluster of warm advection elevated thunderstorms, 1000-1500 J/kg of elevated instability and 40 knots of deep-layer shear allowed storms to produce marginally large hail during the afternoon.

As a result, drought conditions improved by one or more categories across many zones by the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions improved across some of the zone during the month of July. Exceptional (D4) drought improved to the extreme (D3) category across the southern tier of the zone. Meanwhile, exceptional conditions continued over the central areas and even expanded slightly further northward, though the originally present extreme drought over the far north remained unchanged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Amidst a prolonged wet and soggy period, another round of heavy rainfall over central Georgia triggered isolated flash flooding through the day on September 20th. Though much of the flooding occurred during the first half of the day, another localized report of flash flooding was reported late in the evening with another round of shower activity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Emergency Manager relayed multiple reports of flash flooding including road closures and washed out roads in and around the city of Eastman. Some of these reports include Wilson Woodward Road (washed out), from 7th to 9th, MLK Blvd to Cooper Drive, Abbeville Highway, Level Church and near the intersection of Airport Road and Ready Branch Road. Radar estimates indicate that between 4 and 5 inches of rain, with localized areas of up to 8 inches, had fallen over the area in a short period of time, resulting in the flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Amidst a prolonged wet and soggy period, another round of heavy rainfall over central Georgia triggered isolated flash flooding through the day on September 20th. Though much of the flooding occurred during the first half of the day, another localized report of flash flooding was reported late in the evening with another round of shower activity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Emergency Manager reported water over the roadway on Highway 441/Telfair Street. Radar estimates indicate that between 1.5 to 2.5 inches of rain had fallen over the area in a short period of time, resulting in the flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Amidst a prolonged wet and soggy period, another round of heavy rainfall over central Georgia triggered isolated flash flooding through the day on September 20th. Though much of the flooding occurred during the first half of the day, another localized report of flash flooding was reported late in the evening with another round of shower activity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Emergency Manager reported a portion of Panther Branch Road was washed out due to heavy rainfall and high water on nearby creeks. Radar estimates indicate that between 4 and 6 inches of rain had fallen over the area in a short period of time, resulting in the flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoonal moisture pushed northward across western Colorado as the ridge of high pressure tilted eastward. As a result, precipitable water values exceeded an inch over the southern and central zones. Given the increase in midlevel moisture, scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms developed over the region. Some storms produced heavy rain which led to localized debris flows including across portions of the Grizzly Creek Fire burn scar.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: San Miguel Sheriff's Office reported a tree and mud over Colorado Highway 145 as a result of heavy rains.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant monsoon moisture remained in place across the Western Slope. As a result, another round of widespread showers and thunderstorms developed across the area with many storms producing heavy rain. This led to several reports of flash flooding and debris flows across portions of west-central and southwest Colorado. Additionally, severe thunderstorms produced large hail in Norwood.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime to quarter-sized hail accumulated in a yard on the east side of Norwood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike most likely ignited a wildfire 70 miles west of Craig.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Skull Creek Fire began in late July, most likely due to lightning, 70 miles west of Craig. It grew to 104 acres before being contained a few days later.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Substantial monsoon moisture remained over the area as high pressure drifted east over the Plains. As a result, widespread showers and thunderstorms developed with many storms producing heavy rain. This led to several reports of flash flooding and debris flows across portions of southeast Utah including over the Pack Creek Fire burn scar.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain led to a debris flow on the Pack Creek Fire burn scar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged monsoon pattern persisted across much of the region the last couple of weeks of July. The severe drought over the eastern portion of the zone improved to the abnormally dry to moderate drought (D0 to D1) category. The severe conditions that were in place across the southwest portion of the zone at the beginning of the month remained unchanged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A midlevel shortwave trough trekked across the Northern Rockies beneath a weakening ridge. This feature tapped into the already present monsoonal moisture to produce scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms. The stronger storms produced gusty winds in excess of 60 mph across portions of west-central Colorado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A peak wind gust of 63 MPH was measured by the automated Mesonet weather station 2 miles southwest of Parachute.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The prolonged North American Monsoon pattern prevailed across western Colorado with abundant moisture present as precipitable water values trended to 170% of normal. Additionally, morning sunshine allowed the atmosphere to rapidly destabilize over the higher terrain. As a result, another round of strong thunderstorms developed across the region. One storm in Garfield County produced a funnel cloud.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A funnel cloud was spotted roughly in the vicinity of West Mountain in a remote area northwest of Eagle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoonal moisture was once again advected into southwest Colorado as the area of high pressure drifted north. This abundance of moisture combined with weak instability to fuel scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms over the southern mountains. Some storms produced heavy rain which led to localized debris flows across portions of the Southwest San Juans.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A debris flow occurred as a result of heavy rain over Ophir Pass in the Southwest San Juan Mountains. Social media footage showed a combination of rock and mud across the pass with cars having to turn around as a result of the debris flow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front pushed into an unstable and very moist airmass to produce numerous showers and thunderstorms north of Interstate 40 during the afternoon of February 28th. Storms eventually evolved into a line and pushed southeast across the Mid-South. A few severe storms occurred. Heavy rainfall over already saturated soils resulting in some flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight-line winds knocked a large tree onto a house at Brown Avenue near North Evergreen. A child was rescued after being trapped.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred across Tiptonville. Several inches of water flooded one structure.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight-line winds tore the metal roofing off of a barn.

CZ_NAME: COASTAL WATERS FROM SOUTHWEST PASS OF THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER TO PORT FOURCHON LOUISIANA FROM 20 TO 60 NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the daytime hours on March 23rd thru the early morning hours on March 24th, a deep west coast trough helped to deliver progressive yet strong southwesterly upper-level to mid-level moist flow across the northern Gulf coast. At the surface, several waves of strong to severe thunderstorms approached the area from the west, quickly advancing east causing widespread severe thunderstorms across coastal waters from the afternoon on March 23rd through the early morning hours on March 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet Station KMDJ 48nm SE of Leeville measured a peak wind gust of 41 mph or 36 knots from thunderstorm winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station XBIL Biloxi measured a peak wind gust of 41 mph or 36 knots from passing thunderstorms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged monsoon pattern persisted across much of the region the last couple of weeks of July. This led to cooler and unsettled conditions and brought some much needed precipitation to the Western Slope. As a result, drought conditions improved by one or more categories across many zones by the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought remained largely unchanged through the month of July with exceptional (D4) drought persisting over the western portion of the zone and extreme (D3) conditions continuing over the central portions. The severe (D2) drought elsewhere improved to the moderate (D1) category over the far southeast portion of the zone.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure retrograted in response to a deepening mid-level trough over the center of the nation and parked over western Colorado. Even so, subtropical moisture remained entrenched over the area with precipitable water values exceeding an inch and trending over 150% of the climatological norm. As a result, widespread showers and thunderstorms erupted over western Colorado. Additionally, convergence along the Continental Divide enhanced storm coverage. Heavy rain and training was common with storms which led to numerous reports of flash flooding and debris flows, including over the Pine Gulch and Grizzly Creek Fire burn scars.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several inches of water ran across Colorado Highway 145 between mile markers 86 and 88.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged monsoon pattern persisted across much of the region the last couple of weeks of July. This led to cooler and unsettled conditions and brought some much needed precipitation to the Western Slope. As a result, drought conditions improved by one or more categories across many zones by the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought improved across the entirety of the zone through the month of July. Severe (D2) conditions across the far northeast portion of the zone improved to the abnormally dry to moderate drought (D0 to D1) categories. The extreme (D3) drought in the central portion of the zone improved to the severe category. Finally, the exceptional (D4) drought across the southwest portion of the zone improved to the extreme category.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought improved across the entirety of the zone through the month of July. The moderate to severe (D1 to D2) drought across the eastern portion of the zone improved to the abnormally dry (D0) category. The extreme (D3) drought elsewhere improved to the moderate to abnormally dry category for all but the far northern and southern peripheries of the zone which improved to the severe drought.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One of the worst tornado outbreaks ever recorded in the United States struck the Midwest, Ohio Valley, and Tennessee Valley from the evening hours on December 10 into the morning hours on December 11, 2021. Across Middle Tennessee, a total of 16 tornadoes were determined to have touched down, making this the 5th largest tornado outbreak on record in Middle Tennessee. These tornadoes injured 8 people across Middle Tennessee and caused millions of dollars in property and tree damage in many counties. These tornadoes, combined with the 5 tornadoes that occurred just a few days earlier across Middle Tennessee on December 6, 2021, set a new record for the number of tornadoes during the month of December. In addition, many counties that had tornadoes in December 2021 had never recorded a tornado in the month of December before, including Stewart, Humphreys, Cheatham, Wilson, Trousdale, Overton, Pickett, Coffee, and Grundy Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CWOP home weather station EW9547 on Wardley Park Lane measured a wind gust of 69 mph.

Across Middle Tennessee, a total of 16 tornadoes were determined to have touched down, making this the 5th largest tornado outbreak on record in Middle Tennessee. These tornadoes injured 8 people across Middle Tennessee and caused millions of dollars in property and tree damage in many counties. These tornadoes, combined with the 5 tornadoes that occurred just a few days earlier across Middle Tennessee on December 6, 2021, set a new record for the number of tornadoes during the month of December. In addition, many counties that had tornadoes in December 2021 had never recorded a tornado in the month of December before, including Stewart, Humphreys, Cheatham, Wilson, Trousdale, Overton, Pickett, Coffee, and Grundy Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large downburst blew down numerous trees from the Dickson County line eastward across Parker Road and Craggie Hope Road, to the south of the EF-2 Kingston Springs tornado track.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One of the worst tornado outbreaks ever recorded in the United States struck the Midwest, Ohio Valley, and Tennessee Valley from the evening hours on December 10 into the morning hours on December 11, 2021. Across Middle Tennessee, a total of 16 tornadoes were determined to have touched down, making this the 5th largest tornado outbreak on record in Middle Tennessee. These tornadoes injured 8 people across Middle Tennessee and caused millions of dollars in property and tree damage in many counties. These tornadoes, combined with the 5 tornadoes that occurred just a few days earlier across Middle Tennessee on December 6, 2021, set a new record for the number of tornadoes during the month of December. In addition, many counties that had tornadoes in December 2021 had never recorded a tornado in the month of December before, including Stewart, Humphreys, Cheatham, Wilson, Trousdale, Overton, Pickett, Coffee, and Grundy Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This EF-0 tornado touched down on Bright Avenue in South Carthage and moved northeast along the east side of Carthage uprooting several small trees and snapping large tree limbs on Upper Ferry Road, McGinness Avenue, Hillcrest Drive, Skyline Drive, Ridgeway Drive, and Cumberland Mine Road. The tornado then crossed the Horseshoe Bend of the Cumberland River blowing down several trees, then moved across McClures Bend of the Cumberland River and caused tree damage and moderate roof damage to a structure on McClures Bend Lane. The tornado continued east, crossing Sullivan Bend and the Cumberland River yet again before lifting on Waynick Road in Jackson County where it caused minor tree damage. Total path length of this tornado was 7.35 miles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged monsoon pattern persisted across much of the region the last couple of weeks of July. This led to cooler and unsettled conditions and brought some much needed precipitation to the Western Slope. As a result, drought conditions improved by one or more categories across many zones by the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought improved across the majority of the zone through the month of July. The extreme (D3) drought improved to the severe (D2) category across the far eastern portion of the zone. The exceptional (D4) drought over the central areas improved to the extreme category across the northern and southern peripheries while the central portion of the zone improved to the severe category.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the early morning and afternoon hours on May 10th, 2021, two rounds of severe thunderstorms along a stalled frontal boundary produced severe wind gusts across Gulf waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KNEW Lakefront Airport ASOS measured a peak wind gust of 39 mph or 34 knots from thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level weather system pushed a cold front into the Pacific Northwest late Dec. 18th, where the frontal boundary had stalled across southeast Washington and northeast Oregon through Dec. 20th where the stationary frontal boundary had weakened in the afternoon. As a result, bands of rain, freezing rain, and snow were produced across portions of the forecast area during the 19th and 20th, with snow being reported across the lower elevations in the Columbia Basin and mountain locations across southeast Washington and northeast Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter 9 miles NNE of City of The Dalles, OR measured 14 inches of new snow over a 24 hour period ending at 1010 PST on Dec. 20th. A public report 6 miles NNW of Goldendale, WA measured an estimated 8 inches of new snow in a 24 hour period ending 0714 PST on Dec. 20th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level weather system pushed a cold front into the Pacific Northwest late Dec. 18th, where the frontal boundary had stalled across southeast Washington and northeast Oregon through Dec. 20th where the stationary frontal boundary had weakened in the afternoon. As a result, bands of rain, freezing rain, and snow were produced across portions of the forecast area during the 19th and 20th, with snow being reported across the lower elevations in the Columbia Basin and mountain locations across southeast Washington and northeast Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A public report 1 mile NW of Lyle, WA measured 6 inches of new snow in a 24 hour period ending at 1405 PST on Dec. 20th. A trained spotter in White Salmon, WA measured 4 inches of new snow in a 24 hour period ending at 1044 PST on Dec. 20th.

CZ_NAME: EAST SLOPES OF THE OREGON CASCADES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A progressive series of upper level troughs moved through the Pacific Northwest over the Christmas weekend, with persistent moderate snow showers that brought heavy snow accumulations across the east slopes of the Oregon Cascades during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hogg Pass SNOTEL measured 10 inches of new snow over a 17 hour period ending at 0700 PST on Dec. 25th.  A report from the Oregon Department of Transportation 4 miles NW of Black Butte Ranch, OR measured an estimated 13 inches of new snow in 12 hours ending at 0649 PST on Dec. 27th. A Cocorahs observer 2 miles WNW of Sisters, OR measured 12.5 inches of new snow in a 24 hour period ending at 0930 PST on Dec. 27th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level shortwave with a modified arctic cold front brought moderate to heavy snow showers across the Cascades, Blues, and Wallowas, with moderate to heavy snow being observed along the Blue Mountain foothills, and in valley locations across the northeast Oregon mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The cocorahs station OR-WL-3 measured 7 inches of new snow over a 24 hour period ending at 0700 PST on Dec. 31st. Via a social media report 7 miles SE of Joseph, OR, 11 inches of new snow was measured at 1200 PST on Dec. 31st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass was centered over the northern Plains, and Kentucky and southern Indiana were positioned directly along a volatile boundary between the arctic air mass and a warm and moist tropical airmass associated with the Gulf of Mexico. The vertical temperature profile was ideal for the formation of freezing rain. The arctic air wedged itself beneath a warm and moist layer aloft. As energy associated with the jet stream passed over the Ohio Valley, a mix of wintry precipitation occurred. A large swath of freezing rain occurred, stretching mainly west to east across Kentucky.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulation of 0.25 inches was reported in Stanford, KY.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level weather system pushed a cold front into the Pacific Northwest late Dec. 18th, where the frontal boundary had stalled across southeast Washington and northeast Oregon through Dec. 20th where the stationary frontal boundary had weakened in the afternoon. As a result, bands of rain, freezing rain, and snow were produced across portions of the forecast area during the 19th and 20th, with snow being reported across the lower elevations in the Columbia Basin and mountain locations across southeast Washington and northeast Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter 5 miles SSW of Chenoweth, OR measured 7.8 inches if new snow in a 24 hour period. A public report from Arlington, OR estimated that 4 inches of new snow had fallen in a 24 hour period ending at 1026 PST on Dec. 20th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass was centered over the northern Plains, and Kentucky and southern Indiana were positioned directly along a volatile boundary between the arctic air mass and a warm and moist tropical airmass associated with the Gulf of Mexico. The vertical temperature profile was ideal for the formation of freezing rain. The arctic air wedged itself beneath a warm and moist layer aloft. As energy associated with the jet stream passed over the Ohio Valley, a mix of wintry precipitation occurred. A large swath of freezing rain occurred, stretching mainly west to east across Kentucky.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulation greater than a quarter inch occurred over at least the southern half of the county. Numerous vehicle crashes were reported, and KY Highway 69 was closed in both directions due to icy conditions. There were numerous crashes from KY 1265 to KY 144.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass was centered over the northern Plains, and Kentucky and southern Indiana were positioned directly along a volatile boundary between the arctic air mass and a warm and moist tropical airmass associated with the Gulf of Mexico. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around a half inch of ice accumulated in Elizabethtown, Vine Grove, and Radcliff. Extensive tree damage occurred. Power outages were also reported. There was a fatal accident on Interstate 65 northbound at mile marker 91 in Elizabethtown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass was centered over the northern Plains, and Kentucky and southern Indiana were positioned directly along a volatile boundary between the arctic air mass and a warm and moist tropical airmass associated with the Gulf of Mexico. The vertical temperature profile was ideal for the formation of freezing rain. The arctic air wedged itself beneath a warm and moist layer aloft. As energy associated with the jet stream passed over the Ohio Valley, a mix of wintry precipitation occurred. A large swath of freezing rain occurred, stretching mainly west to east across Kentucky.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulation of 0.25 to 0.3 inches occurred across Marion County, KY.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulation of 0.4 inches was reported near Flaherty, KY close to the Hardin County line. 0.25 inches of ice was reported in Brandenburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough and cold front passage at the surface produced snow showers across the Cascade and Blue mountain ranges in Oregon and Washington, while a low level jet associated with this winter storm mixed down strong gusts across the Washington Columbia Basin.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Gable Mountain station belonging to the Hanford Meteorological Monitoring Network (HMMN) 22 miles NNW of Richland, WA measured a peak wind gust of 78 mph at 715 PST. The EOC (HMMN) station 13 miles NW of Richland, WA measured a peak wind gust of 70 mph at 845 PST. 7 miles NNW of Richland, WA, social media reports showed an overturned truck and a travel trailer along State Route 240 in the Hanford area. Local Law enforcement also reported one truck driver was hospitalized due to the accident. Also, 2 miles SE of Kennewick, WA a large tree with a 40 inch circumference base was uprooted by the strong winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough and cold front passage at the surface produced snow showers across the Cascade and Blue mountain ranges in Oregon and Washington, while a low level jet associated with this winter storm mixed down strong gusts across the Washington Columbia Basin.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ski Bluewood measured 10 inches of new snow in a 24 hour period, and 16 inches of new snow over a 48 hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level weather system pushed a cold front into the Pacific Northwest late Dec. 18th, where the frontal boundary had stalled across southeast Washington and northeast Oregon through Dec. 20th where the stationary frontal boundary had weakened in the afternoon. As a result, bands of rain, freezing rain, and snow were produced across portions of the forecast area during the 19th and 20th, with snow being reported across the lower elevations in the Columbia Basin and mountain locations across southeast Washington and northeast Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A social media report from Moro, OR showed 6 inches of new snow was measured over a 24 hour period. A social media report from Dufur estimated that 4.5 inches of new snow had fallen over a 24 hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level weather system pushed a cold front into the Pacific Northwest late Dec. 18th, where the frontal boundary had stalled across southeast Washington and northeast Oregon through Dec. 20th where the stationary frontal boundary had weakened in the afternoon. As a result, bands of rain, freezing rain, and snow were produced across portions of the forecast area during the 19th and 20th, with snow being reported across the lower elevations in the Columbia Basin and mountain locations across southeast Washington and northeast Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An NWS employee 2 miles ENE of Hermiston, OR measured 5 inches of new snow over a 24 hour period. A social media report 4 miles SSW of Hermiston, OR showed that 4 inches of new snow was measured in a 12 hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level shortwave with a modified arctic cold front brought moderate to heavy snow showers across the Cascades, Blues, and Wallowas, with moderate to heavy snow being observed along the Blue Mountain foothills, and in valley locations across the northeast Oregon mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Via a social media report from La Grande, OR, 13 inches of new snow was measured at 0653 PST on Dec. 31st. A CO-OP observer in Cove, OR measured 9.4 inches of new snow at 0800 PST on Dec. 31st.

CZ_NAME: FOOTHILLS OF THE SOUTHERN BLUE MOUNTAINS OF OREGON
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level shortwave with a modified arctic cold front brought moderate to heavy snow showers across the Cascades, Blues, and Wallowas, with moderate to heavy snow being observed along the Blue Mountain foothills, and in valley locations across the northeast Oregon mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Co-Op observer in Heppner, OR measured 6 inches of new snow over a 24 hour period ending at 0800 PST on Dec. 31st. A trained spotter 6 miles W of Condon, OR measured 5 inches of new snow at 1000 PST on Dec. 31st.

CZ_NAME: FOOTHILLS OF THE NORTHERN BLUE MOUNTAINS OF OREGON
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level shortwave with a modified arctic cold front brought moderate to heavy snow showers across the Cascades, Blues, and Wallowas, with moderate to heavy snow being observed along the Blue Mountain foothills, and in valley locations across the northeast Oregon mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cocorahs station OR-UM-11 measured 4.2 inches of new snow over a 24 hour period ending at 0700 PST on Dec. 30th. The NWS office Pendleton measured 5.1 inches of new snow in a 24 hour period ending at 1000 PST on Dec. 30th. A member of the public in Athena, OR reported 6 inches of new snow measured at 1000 PST. Via a social media report from Thorn Hollow, OR, 11 inches of new snow was measured at 0858 PST on Dec. 31st. A trained spotter 4 miles ESE of Pilot Rock, OR measured 5.5 inches of new snow at 1026 PST on Dec. 31st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions worsened slightly across portions of west-central Colorado in response to areas of above normal temperatures and below normal precipitation during the month of June. Conditions improved slightly across portions of southwest Colorado. Elsewhere, the drought status remained unchanged through the end of June as a result of the aforementioned conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought remained largely unchanged across the zone through the month of June as the exceptional (D4) drought persisted over the southern and northwest portions of the zone. Meanwhile, the extreme (D3) category continued and expanded to include the far northeast corner of the zone.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions worsened slightly across portions of west-central Colorado in response to areas of above normal temperatures and below normal precipitation during the month of June. Conditions improved slightly across portions of southwest Colorado. Elsewhere, the drought status remained unchanged through the end of June as a result of the aforementioned conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought remained unchanged through the month of June as the exceptional (D4) category persisted across the zone.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant winter storm with heavy mixed precipitation impacted central Kentucky from late on Valentine's Day through the early morning hours of February 16, 2021. The majority of the precipitation occurred on February 15, 2021. A large swath of 1-3 inches of snow fell in addition to heavy sleet totaling 1-3 inches. Freezing rain and rain mixed in as well, especially in southern and eastern Kentucky. Cold air behind the system brought single digit temperatures, with Lexington plummeting to 2 degrees on the morning of February 17, 2021.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A heavy mix of snow, sleet, and freezing rain fell across Clark County. The freezing rain and sleet combined to produce a 2-inch thick layer of ice in addition to light snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 3 to 4 inches of snow and sleet impacted Scott County, Indiana with the worst weather observed on 2/15/2021.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms developed during the mid afternoon hours in northwest moving into north central Alabama.  A couple of the thunderstorms produced tree damage and small hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was knocked down off of Cowford Road in Athens. Time estimated by radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Hurricane Ida impacted the mid-Atlantic on September 1, 2021. As it moved northward, Ida began transitioning to a strong mid-latitude cyclone with pronounced frontal features, but with continued tropical moisture. On a regional level, the remnants of Ida became one of the most severe natural disasters in US history, due to a combination of several tornadoes, some of them strong, as well as catastrophic flooding over a large and densely populated area. The severe weather threat unfolded as the system's developing warm front lifted northward from the Delmarva region into Pennsylvania and New Jersey. South of the warm front, partial clearing and moderate to strong instability developed. Meanwhile, very strong shear and forcing, along with tropical moisture, were present within the warm sector. The result was widespread convection in the form of both supercell and quasi-linear thunderstorms. A number of storms became severe across the region, producing several tornadoes and other instances of wind damage. This continued an exceptionally active stretch of high end severe weather in the region, coming barely a month after the tornado outbreak of July 29.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down along Emmons Drive along Route 1 in |Princeton, NJ as a remnant supercell moved northward after |producing the Mullica Hill and Burlington, NJ tornadoes earlier |Wednesday afternoon as Ida's remnants moved through the region. |Damage first occurred as several small branches were brought down |along the Whole Foods and Wendy's parking lots along Route 1 in |far eastern Princeton Township, with a continued path of minor |branch damage extending northward along Farber Road, Meadow Drive,|and Canal Pointe Boulevard adjacent to Route 1. Several medium-|size trees were also uprooted with numerous small branches having |been brought down along the western periphery of the Marketfair |shopping parking lot. ||From there, the tornado continued northward with minor tree |damage having occurred along Carnegie Center Boulevard as the |tornado moved northward. Several small branches were also brought |down in a residential area along Heritage Boulevard with one pine |tree even having been snapped. An additional pine tree was also |uprooted along Alexander Road near Glenview. The tornado then |snapped several small hardwood trees, knocking down several |utility poles and power lines along Washington Road. A tree was |also uprooted along Lower Harrison Street along Carnegie Lake |before the tornado lifted somewhere over the lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Hurricane Ida impacted the mid-Atlantic on September 1, 2021. As it moved northward, Ida began transitioning to a strong mid-latitude cyclone with pronounced frontal features, but with continued tropical moisture. On a regional level, the remnants of Ida became one of the most severe natural disasters in US history, due to a combination of several tornadoes, some of them strong, as well as catastrophic flooding over a large and densely populated area. The severe weather threat unfolded as the system's developing warm front lifted northward from the Delmarva region into Pennsylvania and New Jersey. South of the warm front, partial clearing and moderate to strong instability developed. Meanwhile, very strong shear and forcing, along with tropical moisture, were present within the warm sector. The result was widespread convection in the form of both supercell and quasi-linear thunderstorms. A number of storms became severe across the region, producing several tornadoes and other instances of wind damage. This continued an exceptionally active stretch of high end severe weather in the region, coming barely a month after the tornado outbreak of July 29.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The storm which produced a strong tornado in Montgomery County, |PA, cycled and produced another tornado in Bucks County, PA. |Damage began near in the area of Neshaminy Creek between Valley Rd|and Pebble Hill Rd in Doylestown. The tornado tracked north- |northeast from there, producing a consistent path of damage. |Damage was mainly confined to trees and was fairly extensive at |times, with much of the path length being heavily wooded. Numerous|hardwood and softwood trees were snapped and uprooted along the |path. Damage was strongly suggestive of tornadic winds, and a |tornado debris signature was also evident on radar. The heaviest |damage occurred near and along a stretch of Edison- Furlong Rd. |Extensive tree damage occurred along that road and a number of its|cross streets. Several utility poles were snapped in this area. |Tree damage along nearby Swamp Rd was also significant. The |tornado continued but began to lose intensity as it approached |Route 202, with sporadic tree damage observed on Mill Rd. Gradual |weakening continued and the tornado appeared to lift entirely in |the area of Burnt House Hill Rd. The extent of tree damage |suggested maximum winds of around 100 mph. No injuries were |reported as a result of this tornado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Hurricane Ida impacted the mid-Atlantic on September 1, 2021. As it moved northward, Ida began transitioning to a strong mid-latitude cyclone with pronounced frontal features, but with continued tropical moisture. On a regional level, the remnants of Ida became one of the most severe natural disasters in US history, due to a combination of several tornadoes, some of them strong, as well as catastrophic flooding over a large and densely populated area. The severe weather threat unfolded as the system's developing warm front lifted northward from the Delmarva region into Pennsylvania and New Jersey. South of the warm front, partial clearing and moderate to strong instability developed. Meanwhile, very strong shear and forcing, along with tropical moisture, were present within the warm sector. The result was widespread convection in the form of both supercell and quasi-linear thunderstorms. A number of storms became severe across the region, producing several tornadoes and other instances of wind damage. This continued an exceptionally active stretch of high end severe weather in the region, coming barely a month after the tornado outbreak of July 29.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downed trees blocked roadways near Wye Mills. Time estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to the Lehigh Valley of Pennsylvania on the night of September 8.  Rainfall totals were as high as 2 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: PA Route 145 was closed in North Whitehall Township to the south of Laurys Station due to flooding.  There was a water rescue from a vehicle at Second Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The third winter storm in a little more than a week impacted central and eastern Kentucky on February 17-18, 2021. Arctic cold air had pushed far enough south and east by this point that this winter storm featured snow as the dominant precipitation type. Light snow begin during the early evening hours on the 17th. The second wave of this storm exited the region about 24 hours later during the evening of the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snowfall totaling 3-4 inches fell in Hart County, KY with 4 inch totals mainly confined to the southern part of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant winter storm with heavy mixed precipitation impacted central Kentucky from late on Valentine's Day through the early morning hours of February 16, 2021. The majority of the precipitation occurred on February 15, 2021. A large swath of 1-3 inches of snow fell in addition to heavy sleet totaling 1-3 inches. Freezing rain and rain mixed in as well, especially in southern and eastern Kentucky. Cold air behind the system brought single digit temperatures, with Lexington plummeting to 2 degrees on the morning of February 17, 2021.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy sleet and snow totaling 4 inches fell in Jefferson County, KY. About half of this total was in the form of sleet.

Damage occurred downstream of an earlier tornado, but it was inconclusive as to whether this was tornado damage and is believed more likely to be straight line wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass was centered over the northern Plains, and Kentucky and southern Indiana were positioned directly along a volatile boundary between the arctic air mass and a warm and moist tropical airmass associated with the Gulf of Mexico. The vertical temperature profile was ideal for the formation of freezing rain. The arctic air wedged itself beneath a warm and moist layer aloft. As energy associated with the jet stream passed over the Ohio Valley, a mix of wintry precipitation occurred. A large swath of freezing rain occurred, stretching mainly west to east across Kentucky.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulation of 0.3 to 0.5 inches occurred near Springfield, KY.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant winter storm rolled into the Ohio Valley late on Valentine's Day, with the worst weather occurring on February 15, 2021. The storm exited the region on the 16th. Up to a half a foot of snow fell on southern Indiana. Cold air behind the system brought single digit temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall ranging from 4 to 7 inches fell across Dubois County before winding down late on 2/15/2021. Flurries continued into 2/16/2021.

The majority of the precipitation occurred on February 15, 2021. A large swath of 1-3 inches of snow fell in addition to heavy sleet totaling 1-3 inches. Freezing rain and rain mixed in as well, especially in southern and eastern Kentucky. Cold air behind the system brought single digit temperatures, with Lexington plummeting to 2 degrees on the morning of February 17, 2021.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An inch of sleet accumulation was reported in Shelby County, KY. Storm total accumulation of sleet and snow was 2-3 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The third winter storm in a little more than a week impacted central and eastern Kentucky on February 17-18, 2021. Arctic cold air had pushed far enough south and east by this point that this winter storm featured snow as the dominant precipitation type. Light snow begin during the early evening hours on the 17th. The second wave of this storm exited the region about 24 hours later during the evening of the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow of 3.5 to 4 inches fell across Allen County, KY.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions worsened slightly across portions of west-central Colorado in response to areas of above normal temperatures and below normal precipitation during the month of June. Conditions improved slightly across portions of southwest Colorado. Elsewhere, the drought status remained unchanged through the end of June as a result of the aforementioned conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought remained unchanged through the month of June as the exceptional (D4) category persisted across the entirety of the zone.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front moved across a modestly unstable airmass in VT during the late afternoon/evening hours. Scattered thunderstorms developed along this line with a few storms producing some isolated strong winds and most storms very heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees and utility lines downed by thunderstorm winds along Route 116.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Hurricane Ida impacted the mid-Atlantic on September 1, 2021. As it moved northward, Ida began transitioning to a strong mid-latitude cyclone with pronounced frontal features, but with continued tropical moisture. On a regional level, the remnants of Ida became one of the most severe natural disasters in US history, due to a combination of several tornadoes, some of them strong, as well as catastrophic flooding over a large and densely populated area. The severe weather threat unfolded as the system's developing warm front lifted northward from the Delmarva region into Pennsylvania and New Jersey. South of the warm front, partial clearing and moderate to strong instability developed. Meanwhile, very strong shear and forcing, along with tropical moisture, were present within the warm sector. The result was widespread convection in the form of both supercell and quasi-linear thunderstorms. A number of storms became severe across the region, producing several tornadoes and other instances of wind damage. This continued an exceptionally active stretch of high end severe weather in the region, coming barely a month after the tornado outbreak of July 29.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and wires were downed around Cherry Hill. Time estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep vertically stacked low that made it's way from the Bristol Bay area to the Gulf of Alaska. Across southcentral, a strong front along the leading edge of the system brought moderate to heavy snowfall and areas of mixed precipitation in areas affected by down-sloping winds. The backside of the low however brought winds, frigid and blizzard conditions along the southwest.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Saint Paul WSO reported 8.7 inch drifts at the door and 3 ft drifts in the driveway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the early morning hours on May 10th, 2021, slow moving thunderstorms from a stalled frontal boundary delivered flash flooding to portions of the southshore of southeastern Louisiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several underpasses closed due to flooding in the city of New Orleans after 1.5 inches of rain in 30 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the early morning hours on May 10th, 2021, slow moving thunderstorms from a stalled frontal boundary delivered flash flooding to portions of the southshore of southeastern Louisiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous streets flooded in the Metairie area, with several vehicles stalled.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the evening hours on May 2nd, 2021 a moist, unstable airmass south of a northward advancing warm front across coastal Mississippi helped to develop a cluster of strong thunderstorms. These storms impacted portions of southeastern Louisiana, causing severe wind gusts across marine areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: C-MAN Station SHBL1 at shell beach measured a wind gust of 34 knots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the early morning hours on May 5th 2021, a cold front and associated band of showers and storms pushed across portions of southeastern Louisiana. This cluster of storms would eventually slow down as the cold front stalled across the northern Gulf leading to flash flooding across a few locations of southeastern Louisiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report of water covered roads at Viola Street in Mandeville due to flash flooding from heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep vertically stacked low that made it's way from the Bristol Bay area to the Gulf of Alaska. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill at the FAA camera tower at Thompson Pass was -43F at time of issuance. Wind chill values ranged between -38 and -44 through duration of warning. Wind chill values dropped back to -35 around 1300 on the 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another active period across southern Colorado on this day, with showers and thunderstorms observed over much of the area. The eastern mountain and I-25 corridor interface was a location with more widespread development, especially along the Highway 50 corridor. In this area, heavy rainfall with flooding, large hail, and damaging winds were observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred at Indian Creek and Road 421. Eight inches of water was noted, but with no damage.

Isolated to scattered thunderstorms developed over portions of the I-25 corridor in El Paso and Pueblo Counties during the afternoon, and then spread eastward to southeastward across the Highway 50 corridor through the evening. Some of the thunderstorms were strong to severe, with the more intense storms producing large hail of 1-2 inches in diameter and damaging wind gusts of 60-70 mph. Additionally, a tornado and wind gusts up to around 90 mph were observed across the eastern plains on this day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree down in Holly, Colorado.

Southeasterly surface winds across the east resulted in low-level moisture advection which sharpened the dryline across the eastern plains of New Mexico on May 14, 2021. With increasing daytime temperatures, a sufficient amount of instability was in place for afternoon thunderstorms. However, while surface moisture was in place across the east, a lack of mid-level moisture resulted in an environment where strong to damaging winds were the primary threat. Thunderstorms first developed across the northern and southern high terrain of New Mexico before moving eastward onto lower elevations. Thunderstorms that moved onto the plains of eastern New Mexico moved into an environment with more instability and shear which allowed them to intensify. A few of these thunderstorms produced 60 to 70 mph winds, but the hail was sub-severe. Strong downbursts were more common west of the Rio Grande Valley where a couple strong thunderstorms produced downburst winds in excess of 50 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet station near Logan measured a 60 mph wind gust from a decaying thunderstorm producing a strong downburst.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another active period across southern Colorado on this day, with showers and thunderstorms observed over much of the area. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall of 1.00 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak low pressure system tracking eastward across New Mexico on May 7, 2021 resulted in a round of showers and thunderstorms across the area. With easterly to southeasterly surface winds across the east, low-level moisture was more favorable for wetting thunderstorms along and east of the Rio Grande Valley. With modest instability, shear, and lapse rates, there was a threat for strong to severe thunderstorms. A strong thunderstorm that impacted the Albuquerque area produced quarter to half inch hail. Another strong storm in Socorro County near Lemitar produced nickel size hail and wind gusts of 50 to 55 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm chaser near Lemitar reported nickel size hail from a strong thunderstorm.

A few of these thunderstorms produced 60 to 70 mph winds, but the hail was sub-severe. Strong downbursts were more common west of the Rio Grande Valley where a couple strong thunderstorms produced downburst winds in excess of 50 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter near Tolar estimated 60 mph wind gusts from a severe thunderstorm that tracked through the area. The severe winds broke approximately three inch diameter branches off of a tree. Damages are estimated for tree damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated to scattered thunderstorms developed over portions of the I-25 corridor in El Paso and Pueblo Counties during the afternoon, and then spread eastward to southeastward across the Highway 50 corridor through the evening. Some of the thunderstorms were strong to severe, with the more intense storms producing large hail of 1-2 inches in diameter and damaging wind gusts of 60-70 mph. Additionally, a tornado and wind gusts up to around 90 mph were observed across the eastern plains on this day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous large trees are down in Lamar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the early morning hours on May 5th 2021, a cold front and associated band of showers and storms pushed across portions of southeastern Louisiana. This cluster of storms would eventually slow down as the cold front stalled across the northern Gulf leading to flash flooding across a few locations of southeastern Louisiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report of street flooding in the Lakeview area of New Orleans due to heavy rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the overnight hours on May 17th into the early morning on May 18th, a cluster of slow moving severe thunderstorms associated with a weak mid-level disturbance drifted east across southeastern Louisiana. Ample overnight instability and weak steering flow resulted in damaging wind gusts, flash flooding and a few isolated weak tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a home on El Ranchitos Avenue causing a gas line to ignite on a water heater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged monsoon pattern persisted across much of the region the last couple of weeks of July. This led to cooler and unsettled conditions and brought some much needed precipitation to eastern Utah. As a result, drought conditions improved by one or more categories across some southern zones by the end of the month. However, conditions remained unchanged or worsened slightly further north.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought improved across some areas during the month of July. The exceptional (D4) drought over the southern portion of the zone improved to the extreme (D3) category. Elsewhere, the extreme conditions that were in place at the beginning of July remained unchanged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged monsoon pattern persisted across much of the region the last couple of weeks of July. This led to cooler and unsettled conditions and brought some much needed precipitation to eastern Utah. As a result, drought conditions improved by one or more categories across some southern zones by the end of the month. However, conditions remained unchanged or worsened slightly further north.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought remained unchanged through the month of July with exceptional (D4) conditions across all but the far southern portion of the zone where the extreme (D3) category continued.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant monsoon moisture remained in place across the Western Slope. As a result, another round of widespread showers and thunderstorms developed across the area with many storms producing heavy rain. This led to several reports of flash flooding and debris flows across portions of west-central and southwest Colorado. Additionally, severe thunderstorms produced large hail in Norwood.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: San Miguel Sheriff reported that Sanborn Park Road was impassable and closed due to mudslides from heavy rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited a wildfire 20 miles south of Steamboat Springs.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Muddy Slide Fire was started by lightning 20 miles south of Steamboat Springs in mid June. The fire quickly spread and grew to 4,093 acres before finally being contained in mid September.

CZ_NAME: GORE AND ELK MOUNTAINS/CENTRAL MOUNTAIN VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike ignited a wildfire 15 miles south of Eagle near Sylvan State Park.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sylvan Fire began in mid June due to lightning, 15 miles south of Eagle near Sylvan State Park, and grew to 3,792 acres before it was contained in mid October.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad midlevel trough moved across eastern Utah and acted on ample residual monsoonal moisture to produce numerous showers and thunderstorms across the area. Some storms produced gusty winds to 70 mph as well as heavy rain which led to localized debris flows in San Juan County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mud and rocks flowed over La Sal Pass Road as a result of heavy rain over the Pack Creek Fire burn scar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Potential Tropical Cyclone Claudette moved west of the Alabama coastal waters on the evening of June 18th, 2021. Claudette was declared a Tropical Storm and made landfall in southeast Louisiana during the early morning hours of June 19th. Claudette then turned northeast across southeast Mississippi and across south central Alabama during the morning on Saturday June 19th. ||Tropical Storm Claudette produced frequent tropical storm-force wind gusts across coastal Alabama and the western Florida Panhandle. A few areas of the coast, such as Dauphin Island, Fort Morgan, and the Okaloosa Island Fishing Pier recorded a brief period of sustained minimal tropical storm-force winds. ||The highest wind gusts were associated with strong to severe thunderstorms that developed well east of the center of Claudette. These storms most significantly impacted the western Florida Panhandle. The highest wind gust observed was 81 mph at Pensacola International Airport. A Weatherflow site in Santa Rosa Sound recorded a 70 mph wind gust, which was from the same line of storms that resulted in the Pensacola gust. This line of storms produced wind damage in parts of the Pensacola Metro, especially in Ferry Pass. Pace also experienced pockets of wind damage, including one mobile home that lost its roof ||The highest winds recorded were sustained winds of 45 mph with gusts to 70 mph in Santa Rosa Sound, 58 mph with gusts to 81 mph at Pensacola Airport, 42 mph with gusts to 52 mph at Okaloosa Island fishing pier. In Mobile Bay, 40 mph with gusts to 49 mph at Buccaneer Yacht Club. ||Storm surge inundation ranged from 1-3 feet above normally dry ground across southern Mobile County into Mobile Bay. This flooding resulted in the closure of a few roads, such as Shell Belt Rd in the Bayou La Batre and Coden communities and the US Highway 90 Causeway over Mobile Bay. The highest storm tide recorded was 3.67 ft MHHW at the NOS tide gauge on the Bayou La Batre bridge. In addition to the storm surge, surf heights of 6-12 feet battered the Gulf facing beaches. This impacted the west end of Dauphin Island with a portion of Bienville Blvd closed due to flooding and sand over the road. The Florida side of the Gulf Islands National Seashore was closed for several days due to flooding and sand on roads. ||Claudette produced 3 tornadoes in southwest and south central Alabama: A long track EF-2 tornado that impacted Escambia and Conecuh Counties, an EF-0 tornado in rural Covington County, and an EF-0 tornado in far southern Mobile County. ||A widespread 3-6 of rain fell across coastal Alabama into the western Florida Panhandle. 6-9 of rain was recorded over parts of interior southeast MS, with a station in far western Stone County, 11 miles west of Perkinston, recording 9.43. This rainfall resulted in instances of flash flooding and river flooding across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused water to cover the road in these areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged monsoon pattern persisted across much of the region the last couple of weeks of July. This led to cooler and unsettled conditions and brought some much needed precipitation to eastern Utah. As a result, drought conditions improved by one or more categories across some southern zones by the end of the month. However, conditions remained unchanged or worsened slightly further north.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought either worsened or improved across some areas during the month of July. The exceptional (D4) drought was trimmed back to include only the far southern portion of the zone by the end of the month. Elsewhere, the extreme (D3) drought expanded north to include the rest of the zone.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The prolonged North American Monsoon pattern prevailed across western Colorado with abundant moisture present as precipitable water values trended to 170% of normal. Additionally, morning sunshine allowed the atmosphere to rapidly destabilize over the higher terrain. As a result, another round of strong thunderstorms developed and produced heavy rain which caused several mudslides across portions of west-central Colorado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A rockslide occurred as a result of heavy rain along Colorado Highway 82 at Shane Bluffs (mile marker 36).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moist and unstable environment brought scattered thunderstorms producing frequent cloud-to-ground lightning to the San Juan Mountains in Southwest Colorado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three firefighters working during the mopping up stages on the Johnny Canyon Fire east of Baldy Mountain were caught in a thunderstorm near the 9500 foot level. The thunderstorm intensified overhead with heavy rain, hail and continuous lightning. The crew decided to hunker down in place and wait for the storm to pass. After hearing a large thunderclap, the crew decided they needed to move down the mountain to a safer location. While hiking out, the crew passed through a metal fence gate when one firefighter saw a lightning strike very close by. He saw it split between a tree and the metal fence and immediately felt tingling and cramping in his feet and lower back. Another firefighter was in the process of latching the metal fence gate when he felt a jolt go through his harm and his arm tingling. There were no serious injuries between the three firefighters and all refused treatment, even though they were shivering badly and were experiencing the early stages of hypothermia from being exposed to the heavy rain and hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An adult male drowned at Pensacola Beach as the result of a rip current.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An adult male drowned as the result of a rip current at Pensacola Beach. Lifeguards rescued him from the water, but he was pronounced deceased at the scene.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 63 year old male from northern Alabama (Athens, AL) died after getting caught in a rip current on the Ft Morgan peninsula on Wednesday morning. Bystanders were able to pull the vacationer out of the water, but numerous CPR and revival attempts were unsuccessful.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 63 year old male from northern Alabama (Athens, AL) died after getting caught in a rip current on the Ft Morgan peninsula on Wednesday morning. Bystanders were able to pull the vacationer out of the water, but numerous CPR and revival attempts were unsuccessful.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Baldwin County Sheriff Deputy (male, 57 years old) died after rescuing swimmers during a swimmer in distress call around 6pm on Ft. Morgan. Four swimmers needed to be rescued from the Gulf waters. Another deputy who assisted in the rescue was hospitalized but recovered.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Baldwin County Sheriff Deputy (male, 57 years old) died after rescuing swimmers during a swimmer in distress call around 6pm on Ft. Morgan. Four swimmers needed to be rescued from the Gulf waters. Another deputy who assisted in the rescue was hospitalized but recovered.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep monsoon moisture continued across northern Arizona with several flash floods.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep monsoon moisture continued across northern Arizona with several flash floods.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain over the southern slopes of Mt Elden caused flash flooding in northeast Flagstaff.  The water overwhelmed drainage systems and was flowing rapidly down streets (up to two feet deep). A video on social media showed a Prius floating down the street and crashing into a full sized pick-up truck.  Water was flowing 6 feet deep in a low water crossing.  Famous Route 66 had 2 feet of water flowing over it in town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep monsoon moisture continued across northern Arizona with several flash floods.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A flash flood rushed down the Tatahatso Wash/Slot Canyon into the Colorado River (38 miles down stream from Lees Ferry). A commercial river trip with 30 people and two large raft had set up camp at the mouth of the wash for the night. The flash flood washed away the camp. Four people were injured and one person died.

On Wednesday May 19, 2021, an upper level Pacific trough dove south through the Pacific Northwest into the Great Basin and then became nearly stationary for a couple of days. The southerly flow ahead of this system transported middle and upper level moisture into the state, while an upslope east to northeast flow developed at the lower levels in response to relatively strong surface high and low pressure systems respectively set up over Alberta Canada and Utah.  The upslope flow eventually led to cold air damming and the development of a low level barrier jet along the Divide.  This resulted in strong northerly surface winds along eastern slopes adjacent to the Rocky Mountain Front for periods of near blizzard conditions and subsequently sent the unseasonably cold air into the southwestern portion of the state.  Locations from Rogers Pass northward into the East Glacier and Browning areas observed the worst conditions due to the combination of falling snow and gusty northerly winds. The impacts ranged from severe driving conditions on area roadways to isolated power outages. By Thursday morning, the rain began to change to snow at lower elevations over North-central Montana and this transition eventually reached the southwest valleys later that evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter at 7 SE Rocky Boy reported a 14 inch snow total.

The southerly flow ahead of this system transported middle and upper level moisture into the state, while an upslope east to northeast flow developed at the lower levels in response to relatively strong surface high and low pressure systems respectively set up over Alberta Canada and Utah.  The upslope flow eventually led to cold air damming and the development of a low level barrier jet along the Divide.  This resulted in strong northerly surface winds along eastern slopes adjacent to the Rocky Mountain Front for periods of near blizzard conditions and subsequently sent the unseasonably cold air into the southwestern portion of the state.  Locations from Rogers Pass northward into the East Glacier and Browning areas observed the worst conditions due to the combination of falling snow and gusty northerly winds. The impacts ranged from severe driving conditions on area roadways to isolated power outages. By Thursday morning, the rain began to change to snow at lower elevations over North-central Montana and this transition eventually reached the southwest valleys later that evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts of 12 inches reported near Heart Butte. Reduced visibility and flickering electricity was also reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong pressure gradient, coupled with strong 60-80 knot winds at the mid levels, resulted in yet another round of gusty winds across the Plains of North-Central Montana, as well as a few areas in Southwest Montana, particularly in Madison County. Some snow also fell with this system, with 12 inches of snow reported at Teton Pass Ski Resort and 14 inches along the MT-ID border near West Yellowstone.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts to 65 mph were measured across Judith Basin County through the day, with the highest wind gust of 65 mph recorded at Benchland at 8:45 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the overnight hours on May 17th into the early morning on May 18th, a cluster of slow moving severe thunderstorms associated with a weak mid-level disturbance drifted east across southeastern Louisiana. Ample overnight instability and weak steering flow resulted in damaging wind gusts, flash flooding and a few isolated weak tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Chadsford Avenue impassable due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Recycled moisture underneath a ridge of high pressure was enough to fuel isolated to scattered showers across western Colorado. As these showers decayed they produced gusty outflow winds with some gusts meeting high wind criteria in Mesa County. Two semi trucks rolled over along Interstate 70 as a result of the high winds and shut down portions of the interstate for a short while.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Colorado State Patrol reported two semi trucks rolled over off of Interstate 70 between exit 11 towards Mack and exit 2 towards Rabbit Valley. The accidents occurred between 9:30 and 9:54 PM MDT. Automated sensors recorded peak wind gusts between 58 and 63 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple lightning strikes caused a wildfire in a remote area, 23 miles south of Rangely.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Oil Springs Fire was started by lightning and was approximately 23 miles south of Rangely. It grew to 12,613 acres before it was contained in mid July. Colorado Hwy 139 was closed from Fruita to north of Douglas Pass for a while due to the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread heavy rain showers and scattered thunderstorms developed north of a warm front across western North Carolina throughout the 25th into the 26th. Widespread totals rainfall of 3 to 6 inches, with locally higher amounts resulted in minor to moderate flooding along several mainstem rivers and some tributaries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A stream gauge reported flooding developed along Mud Creek after 4.5 to 6 inches of rain fell across Henderson County, mostly in about a 12-hour period from the 25th into the early part of the 27th. Impacted roads included an access road at the intersection of S Church St and S Main St and Kanuga Rd at Erkwood Dr.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southeasterly surface winds across the east resulted in low-level moisture advection which sharpened the dryline across the eastern plains of New Mexico on May 14, 2021. With increasing daytime temperatures, a sufficient amount of instability was in place for afternoon thunderstorms. However, while surface moisture was in place across the east, a lack of mid-level moisture resulted in an environment where strong to damaging winds were the primary threat. Thunderstorms first developed across the northern and southern high terrain of New Mexico before moving eastward onto lower elevations. Thunderstorms that moved onto the plains of eastern New Mexico moved into an environment with more instability and shear which allowed them to intensify. A few of these thunderstorms produced 60 to 70 mph winds, but the hail was sub-severe. Strong downbursts were more common west of the Rio Grande Valley where a couple strong thunderstorms produced downburst winds in excess of 50 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An ASOS station in Roswell measured a 69 mph thunderstorm wind gust from a severe thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Daytime heating helped fuel storms as they developed along a cold front that passed through Northeastern Pennsylvania. Locally heavy rainfall produced areas of flash flooding and related damages in the region.
