EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and evening hours ahead of a cold front approaching the Ohio Valley Region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several inches of water were flowing across U.S. Route 421 in Napoleon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening hours as a low pressure system moved through a warm and humid airmass that was in place across the Ohio Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were downed in the Hebron and Burlington areas, including along Camp Ernst Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain brought localized flooding to Fulton County on Sunday April 11th.  Flooding on Licking Creek in Needmore, PA resulted in one fatality when a man drove over a flooded bridge.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain resulted in flooding on Licking Creek. A man crossing a flooded road, was swept away, and was later found deceased.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front moving through the Ohio Valley. Some of the storms produced heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was rushing over the road near the intersection of Trackville Road and Hickory Road. People needed to be rescued from a vehicle trapped in the high water along Trackville Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe weather only briefly clipped the far southeastern fringes of this six-county North Central Kansas  area on this Friday afternoon, but it was nonetheless an active hour or so within south-central Mitchell County, as a short-lived, semi-isolated severe storm entered the local area out of Lincoln County around 4:30 p.m. CDT, peaked in intensity between 5:00-5:30 p.m. CDT and then rapidly dissipated. The only ground-truth report of severe weather came from a CoCoRaHS observer, who noted that severe winds (estimated around 65 MPH) destroyed a farm outbuilding and caused crop damage approximately eight miles south-southwest of Beloit.||This storm first developed/intensified slightly south of the local area over the Russell/Lincoln County border area around 4 p.m. CDT, along a well-defined late summer cold front gradually progressing across the region from west-to-east. Only about 90 minutes later, it quickly weakened over east-central Mitchell County, signaling the end of any severe weather threat within the local area for the remainder of the afternoon-evening, as all further severe activity focused off to both the east and south. In the mid-upper levels, forcing was seasonably-decent, with North Central Kansas receiving a glancing blow from a potent, negatively-tilted shortwave trough swinging northeastward across the Dakotas during the afternoon-evening. However, the aforementioned surface cold front was the main synoptic feature in play, trailing southward through eastern portions of North Central Kansas at mid-afternoon from a deepening 1000-millibar low pressure center over eastern ND. Along and just ahead of this front a very unstable airmass awaited, with the surface temperature/dewpoint in the Mitchell County area at 4 p.m. CDT registering around 94/72 (F). Around this same time, mesoscale parameters featured 3000-4000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of deep-layer wind shear.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local CoCoRaHS observer noted that severe winds (estimated around 65 MPH) destroyed a farm outbuilding and caused crop damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening hours as a low pressure system moved through a warm and humid airmass that was in place across the Ohio Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were downed in the Boone County Arboretum.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening hours as a low pressure system moved through a warm and humid airmass that was in place across the Ohio Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were downed near exit 171 on I-75.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening hours as a low pressure system moved through a warm and humid airmass that was in place across the Ohio Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were downed in the Thunder Ridge Subdivision.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours across the Ohio Valley ahead of an upper level low pressure system moving through the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several people were rescued from their homes along Main Street due to rising water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed during the afternoon in a warm and humid airmass. A few of the storms produced locally heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several cars were stranded in one to two feet of standing water in the city of Portsmouth. A few basements also flooded in low lying areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and evening hours ahead of a cold front approaching the Ohio Valley Region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed in Jaysville, near County Road 36.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening hours as a low pressure system moved through a warm and humid airmass that was in place across the Ohio Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The first sign of tornadic damage was observed just east of the Indiana/Ohio state line. Trees were snapped along Park Road, indicative of EF0 tornado damage. The tornado then moved southeast and may have briefly lifted, before touching back down and leaving a noticeable swirl in a wheat field between St Joe Road and Wabash Road. The tornado intensified as it moved across Wabash Road, impacting the Fort Recovery Lumber Yard. Multiple roofs were completely lifted off several outbuildings. Additionally, a collapsed cinder block wall was observed at the Fort Recovery Lumber Yard. This was consistent with EF1 damage.||The tornado then continued moving southeast through wooded areas between Wabash Road and Fort Recovery-Minster Road. Hardwood tree damage was noted in the wooded areas. After crossing Fort Recovery-Minster Road, partial removal of an outbuilding roof was noted along with tree damage. More significant damage then became apparent as the tornado continued southeast impacting the Burrville Road/Hart Road area. Multiple homes along Burrville Road sustained substantial roof damage, including total removal of over half the roof of a single family home. The survey team also noted completely destroyed outbuildings, the removal of attached garages, substantial tree damage, and projectiles embedded within an exterior wall.||Several wood power poles along Burrville Road were also completely broken. Debris from Burrville Road was thrown approximately a half mile toward Wourms Road. In addition, the tornado produced damage along Wourms Road, which included more broken wood power poles. The wooded area along Wourms Road also exhibited the most significant tree damage, where numerous hardwood trees were snapped or knocked over. Damage along Burrville Road and Wourms Road was consistent with low end EF2 damage, with maximum winds of around 115 mph.||The tornado seemed to rapidly weaken as it moved southeast to Fox Road and Meiring Road. The only damage seen was minor damage to an outbuilding and partial removal of the top of a silo. No additional damage was observed to the southeast of this area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening hours as a low pressure system moved through a warm and humid airmass that was in place across the Ohio Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado initially touched down on the west side of Puddenbag Road, south of Barlow Road and damaged several groves of trees before crossing Puddenbag Road and snapping and uprooting several more groves of trees on the east side of Puddenbag Road.  The tornado crossed in front of a farmstead and snapped and uprooted a number of trees in front of the residence. It was at this location where tree damage was estimated to be caused by winds in the 90-95 mph range. The tornado continued southeast to Oxford Road where roofing material was lifted from a home on the north side of the road and a barn on the south side of the road, while also continuing to cause considerable tree damage. The tornado then continued southeast and moved into Butler County about 0.8 miles south southwest of Browns Chapel. The tornado continued to move southeast across far northern Butler County before lifting 1 mile northeast of Astoria at 19:43 EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Patches of dense fog formed into the early morning of September 5th around the San Francisco Bay Area and down to Monterey. Observations ranged from 1/8 of a mile to 2 miles in affected areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KPIX webcam on Salesforce Tower in downtown San Francisco as well as satellite imagery and other public reports showed fog in downtown San Francisco. Conditions began to improve mid to late morning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent warm front with some elevated convection produced isolated to scattered thunderstorms across northern NY during the early morning hours of September 15th. One such storm in Brushton briefly produced a wind gust that knocked a tree onto some power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree on wires on Delancy Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across a moderately unstable air mass across central and southern VT during the afternoon of September 15th. Showers and thunderstorms developed in the southern Champlain Valley and Upper Hudson Valley of New York and moved into central and southern VT. Some of these storms intensified across VT delivering isolated to scattered wind damage to trees and utility lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree on powerlines on Plain road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Patches of dense fog formed into the early morning of September 5th around the San Francisco Bay Area and down to Monterey. Observations ranged from 1/8 of a mile to 2 miles in affected areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Santa Rosa Airport ASOS reported visibility down to a quarter of a mile.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought strong (both thunderstorm, and non-thunderstorm) winds, tornadoes, dust, snow, and record temperatures into eastern Nebraska and western Iowa. The event was determined to be a derecho meeting the criteria of wind damage extending more than 250 miles, including wind gusts of at least 58 mph and numerous gusts of at least 75 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public report via mping of 3-inch tree limbs broken; power poles broken.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought strong (both thunderstorm, and non-thunderstorm) winds, tornadoes, dust, snow, and record temperatures into eastern Nebraska and western Iowa. The event was determined to be a derecho meeting the criteria of wind damage extending more than 250 miles, including wind gusts of at least 58 mph and numerous gusts of at least 75 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported that a large tree limb crushed a car and downed a fence.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent storm system affected Central Alabama on Thursday, March 25th. A highly-sheared environment combined with increasing instability produced numerous tornadic thunderstorms. Severe parameters were supportive of significant and long-track supercells, prompting the issuance of a rare High Risk Convective Outlook from the Storm Prediction Center for portions of Central Alabama.||A total of 10 tornado tracks were surveyed in Central Alabama. This included 4 EF3 tornadoes, 3 EF2 tornadoes, and 3 EF1 tornadoes. Damage was significant along the paths of the most intense tornadoes and, unfortunately, injuries and fatalities occurred. |Some storms were cyclic, meaning multiple tornadoes were produced by the same storm. The most impressive tornado of the event was the long-track tornado that traveled nearly 80 miles from Hale County to Shelby County. This ranked as the seventh longest single tornado track in the state of Alabama.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: National Weather Service meteorologists surveyed damage in southern Cherokee County and determined that it was consistent with an EF0 tornado, with maximum winds near 80 mph.||This tornado originated in Calhoun County and crossed into Cherokee County just west of Highway 9. The tornado tracked northeast and crossed Highway 9 and County Road 33. The tornado was in a weakening phase once it crossed into Cherokee County and dissipated just east of County Road 29. Damage consisted mostly of uprooted trees.

Damage was significant along the paths of the most intense tornadoes and, unfortunately, injuries and fatalities occurred. |Some storms were cyclic, meaning multiple tornadoes were produced by the same storm. The most impressive tornado of the event was the long-track tornado that traveled nearly 80 miles from Hale County to Shelby County. This ranked as the seventh longest single tornado track in the state of Alabama.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: National Weather Service meteorologists surveyed damage in northern Greene County and determined that it was consistent with an EF1 tornado, with maximum winds near 100 mph.||This tornado touched down along County Road 174 and crossed Highway 14 between Clinton and Eutaw. It continued northeastward, snapping numerous trees along County Road 181 and County Road 199. The tornado then weakened with sparse tree damage, dissipating along County Road 218.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening hours as a low pressure system moved through a warm and humid airmass that was in place across the Ohio Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines were downed across central and southeast portions of Wayne County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening hours as a low pressure system moved through a warm and humid airmass that was in place across the Ohio Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell onto a house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening hours as a low pressure system moved through a warm and humid airmass that was in place across the Ohio Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines were downed across the northern and eastern portions of Ripley County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening hours as a low pressure system moved through a warm and humid airmass that was in place across the Ohio Valley.
Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening hours as a low pressure system moved through a warm and humid airmass that was in place across the Ohio Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A business sustained roof damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm and humid airmass across the Ohio Valley resulted in scattered thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water was reported on County Road 50, just east of State Route 129.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following the departure of the slow moving low pressure system which brought low elevation snowfall to portions of central California and disrupted holiday travel on December 29 and 30, upslope flow over the Tehachapi Mountains resulted in low clouds banking up producing dense fog in the Tehachapi Valley and to the north of Tejon Pass along interstate 5 which further disrupted holiday travelers during the evening of December 30 until the early afternoon of December 31.  In addition, areas of dense fog formed for a few hours in the San Joaquin Valley where skies cleared out, disrupting travel along SR 99 during the morning of December 31 until the fog lifted into a low cloud deck.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol paced traffic on Interstate 5 south of Fort Tejon to Tejon Pass as a result of visibility below 1000 feet.

CZ_NAME: SOUTH END OF THE UPPER SIERRA
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level shortwave system which dropped southeast through the Great Basin on December 31 produced increased surface pressure gradients which resulted in strong downslope winds along the Mojave Desert slopes of the Tehachapi Mountains during the afternoon and evening hours.  Several stations measured wind gusts exceeding 45 mph with a few stations reporting gusts exceeding 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bird Springs Pass RAWS measured a peak wind gust of 65 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level shortwave system which dropped southeast through the Great Basin on December 31 produced increased surface pressure gradients which resulted in strong downslope winds along the Mojave Desert slopes of the Tehachapi Mountains during the afternoon and evening hours.  Several stations measured wind gusts exceeding 45 mph with a few stations reporting gusts exceeding 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Southern California Edison station at Cache Creek measured a peak wind gust of 66 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level shortwave system which dropped southeast through the Great Basin on December 31 produced increased surface pressure gradients which resulted in strong downslope winds along the Mojave Desert slopes of the Tehachapi Mountains during the afternoon and evening hours.  Several stations measured wind gusts exceeding 45 mph with a few stations reporting gusts exceeding 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cache Creek CHP station measured a peak wind gust of 64 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of nearby strong thunderstorms and a passing pneumonia front resulted in several periods of strong wind gusts affecting the Lake Michigan shoreline in the Sheboygan area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sheboygan lakeshore weather station measured a strong wind gust from the north as nearby thunderstorms affected the area along with a passing pneumonia front.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of nearby strong thunderstorms and a passing pneumonia front resulted in several periods of strong wind gusts affecting the Lake Michigan shoreline in the Sheboygan area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sheboygan lakeshore weather station measured a north wind gusts to 40 knots in the early evening from passing nearby strong thunderstorms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Pacific trough and attendant cold front brought increased westerly flow aloft and just enough of a surface pressure gradient for strong surface winds along the Rocky Mountain Front and the immediate adjoining plains. H700 winds were not overly strong at around 40 to 45 kts, but were two to three standard deviations above what is normally expected for the middle of May.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cut Bank Airport measured a 53 kt (61 mph) non-thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Pacific trough and attendant cold front brought increased westerly flow aloft and just enough of a surface pressure gradient for strong surface winds along the Rocky Mountain Front and the immediate adjoining plains. H700 winds were not overly strong at around 40 to 45 kts, but were two to three standard deviations above what is normally expected for the middle of May.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: MDT Two Medicine Bridge station measured a 53 kt (61 mph) non-thunderstorm wind gust.

CZ_NAME: MOUNTAINS SOUTHWESTERN SHASTA COUNTY TO WESTERN COLUSA COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The McFarland Fire started by lightning on July 29th near McFarland Ridge, south of Highway 36 near Wildwood, California. The fire started in an area under drought conditions with hot weather and exceptionally dry vegetation in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The McFarland Fire was started by lightning on July 29th near McFarland Ridge, south of Highway 36 near Wildwood, California. The fire burned 122,653 acres. The fire made an over-40,000 acre run from August 16th to August 17th. The fire caused evacuations in the Platina area. 24 residential structures and 22 other structures were destroyed, and 1 residential structure was damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over California resulted in very hot daytime temperatures and warm overnight low temperatures across interior Northern California. High to very high heat risk impacted the region. Two daily high temperature records were broken. During the event, cooling centers were made available to the public across interior Northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake Shasta Dam area saw high temperatures reach 110 to 114 degrees during the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening hours as a low pressure system moved through a warm and humid airmass that was in place across the Ohio Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado likely began in a wooded area behind Longbranch Road, where downed trees were first noted. The most significant damage occurred at two residences on Longbranch Road. Nearly half of the metal roof of one residence was lifted and thrown in multiple directions, with insulation splattered on the residence and even onto parked vehicles. Trees on both properties were knocked down or blown over in multiple directions and the tree damage exhibited a very convergent pattern. The tornado is believed to have lifted in another wooded area to the southeast of Longbranch Road, as no other damage was seen on any roads to the southeast.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening hours as a low pressure system moved through a warm and humid airmass that was in place across the Ohio Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines were blown down across Dearborn County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening hours as a low pressure system moved through a warm and humid airmass that was in place across the Ohio Valley.
Scattered thunderstorms developed and moved southwest across Graham, Greenlee and Cochise counties. One storm produced damaging winds in the Sierra Vista area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds downed seven power poles and damaged or destroyed several storage sheds near Moson Rd, between Dakota and Nevada Aves.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed and moved slowly west across southeast Arizona. Large hail was reported near Rio Rico with flash flooding of Arivaca Rd. in northwest Santa Cruz and southeast Pima counties.

Low pressure intensified on December 10 as it moved from the lee of the central Rockies into the Great Lakes. A strong frontogenetic band developed ahead of the system, with weak instability present which resulted in a narrow and more intense band across parts of southeast South Dakota. Extreme northeast Nebraska was on the sharp southern gradient of heavy snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall was moderate to briefly heavy between 1300-1700CST, which produced dangerous travel conditions. Snowfall totaled 4.0 inches at Emerson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unprecedented storm system lifted across the central Plains from December 15 into the early hours of December 16. Kinematic fields were at the top of the climatological distributions, leading to extreme wind shear in the lowest levels. Ahead of the system, record high temperatures with surface dew point values into the 50s and lower 60s surged toward northwest Iowa and resulted in instability not typically found in December.||A serial derecho developed across Nebraska and Kansas during the early afternoon and raced to the northeast toward Iowa and Minnesota, with widespread damaging wind and a few tornadoes.||As the cold front swung through the area behind the convective line, 60 to 75 mph winds aloft were mixed to the surface and resulted in a few synoptic wind gusts up to hurricane force. Some light wintry precipitation also fell during the transition toward the much colder air, which led to flash freezing as temperatures fell as much as 40 degrees during the overnight hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds reached 40 to 45 mph during the evening, with a peak wind gust of 67 mph at the nearby Sioux Gateway Airport (KSUX).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season severe weather outbreak occurred across New Hampshire as a cold front swept across the state during the afternoon peak heating.  A very moist and unstable airmass was in place across the region with highs reaching 80 degrees and dewpoints into the 60s.  This allowed for sufficient CAPE values to support damaging winds gusts and large hail as the cold front moved across the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Damaging outflow wind gusts from a severe thunderstorm downed numerous trees across the town of Lancaster.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One of the worst tornado outbreaks ever recorded in the United States struck the Midwest, Ohio Valley, and Tennessee Valley from the evening hours on December 10 into the morning hours on December 11, 2021. Across Middle Tennessee, a total of 16 tornadoes were determined to have touched down, making this the 5th largest tornado outbreak on record in Middle Tennessee. These tornadoes injured 8 people across Middle Tennessee and caused millions of dollars in property and tree damage in many counties. These tornadoes, combined with the 5 tornadoes that occurred just a few days earlier across Middle Tennessee on December 6, 2021, set a new record for the number of tornadoes during the month of December. In addition, many counties that had tornadoes in December 2021 had never recorded a tornado in the month of December before, including Stewart, Humphreys, Cheatham, Wilson, Trousdale, Overton, Pickett, Coffee, and Grundy Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This EF-2 tornado touched down near Highway 70 between White Bluff and Kingston Springs, blowing down a few trees and causing roof damage to a few homes in Dickson County. Moving into Cheatham County while staying north of Highway 70, there was severe roof damage to homes on Sneed Road and dozens of trees were snapped. Many more homes and a few businesses and churches suffered roof damage and dozens of trees were blown down further to the east along Highway 70, Butterworth Road, and Old Butterworth Road. Several outbuildings collapsed, more homes and churches were damaged, and power poles blown down further eastward along Highway 70 and Cedar Hill Road. The tornado continued northeastward across rural areas of southeastern Cheatham County, blowing down more trees and damaging roofs and outbuildings along Sams Creek Road, Indian Springs Road and Pond Creek Road before the tornado lifted just east of the Davidson County line. The track of this tornado was adjusted using high resolution NASA satellite imagery. Total path length of this tornado was 12.61 miles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One of the worst tornado outbreaks ever recorded in the United States struck the Midwest, Ohio Valley, and Tennessee Valley from the evening hours on December 10 into the morning hours on December 11, 2021. Across Middle Tennessee, a total of 16 tornadoes were determined to have touched down, making this the 5th largest tornado outbreak on record in Middle Tennessee. These tornadoes injured 8 people across Middle Tennessee and caused millions of dollars in property and tree damage in many counties. These tornadoes, combined with the 5 tornadoes that occurred just a few days earlier across Middle Tennessee on December 6, 2021, set a new record for the number of tornadoes during the month of December. In addition, many counties that had tornadoes in December 2021 had never recorded a tornado in the month of December before, including Stewart, Humphreys, Cheatham, Wilson, Trousdale, Overton, Pickett, Coffee, and Grundy Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell across Highway 136.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continued dry conditions across western Colorado allowed the drought to persist across the region through the month of November with some area's categories worsening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought remained unchanged across the entirety of the zone through the month of November as severe (D2) drought persisted across all but the far southern portion of the zone where moderate (D1) conditions continued.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continued dry conditions across western Colorado allowed the drought to persist across the region through the month of November with some area's categories worsening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The status of the drought improved across portions of the zone through the month of November as the severe (D2) drought improved to the moderate (D1) category over the western half of the zone. Elsewhere, the severe (D2) drought continued.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One of the worst tornado outbreaks ever recorded in the United States struck the Midwest, Ohio Valley, and Tennessee Valley from the evening hours on December 10 into the morning hours on December 11, 2021. Across Middle Tennessee, a total of 16 tornadoes were determined to have touched down, making this the 5th largest tornado outbreak on record in Middle Tennessee. These tornadoes injured 8 people across Middle Tennessee and caused millions of dollars in property and tree damage in many counties. These tornadoes, combined with the 5 tornadoes that occurred just a few days earlier across Middle Tennessee on December 6, 2021, set a new record for the number of tornadoes during the month of December. In addition, many counties that had tornadoes in December 2021 had never recorded a tornado in the month of December before, including Stewart, Humphreys, Cheatham, Wilson, Trousdale, Overton, Pickett, Coffee, and Grundy Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This small EF-0 tornado was determined through a combination of NWS storm surveys, NASA satellite imagery, and radar data, and touched down near Belotes Ferry Road in far northern Wilson County where it blew down a few trees. The tornado crossed the Cumberland River into the Belotes Bend area of Sumner County where it blew down dozens of trees in a narrow swath across inaccessible rural areas south of Harsh Lane and Preacher Robertson Road. The tornado again crossed the Cumberland River back into Wilson County where it continued to blow down trees in the Lytles Bend area west of Canoe Branch Road before lifting. Total path length of this tornado was 3.07 miles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One of the worst tornado outbreaks ever recorded in the United States struck the Midwest, Ohio Valley, and Tennessee Valley from the evening hours on December 10 into the morning hours on December 11, 2021. Across Middle Tennessee, a total of 16 tornadoes were determined to have touched down, making this the 5th largest tornado outbreak on record in Middle Tennessee. These tornadoes injured 8 people across Middle Tennessee and caused millions of dollars in property and tree damage in many counties. These tornadoes, combined with the 5 tornadoes that occurred just a few days earlier across Middle Tennessee on December 6, 2021, set a new record for the number of tornadoes during the month of December. In addition, many counties that had tornadoes in December 2021 had never recorded a tornado in the month of December before, including Stewart, Humphreys, Cheatham, Wilson, Trousdale, Overton, Pickett, Coffee, and Grundy Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This EF-0 tornado touched down on Bright Avenue in South Carthage and moved northeast along the east side of Carthage uprooting several small trees and snapping large tree limbs on Upper Ferry Road, McGinness Avenue, Hillcrest Drive, Skyline Drive, Ridgeway Drive, and Cumberland Mine Road. The tornado then crossed the Horseshoe Bend of the Cumberland River blowing down several trees, then moved across McClures Bend of the Cumberland River and caused tree damage and moderate roof damage to a structure on McClures Bend Lane. The tornado continued east, crossing Sullivan Bend and the Cumberland River yet again before lifting on Waynick Road in Jackson County where it caused minor tree damage. Total path length of this tornado was 7.35 miles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front was moving through the area. Out ahead of it was plenty of moisture due to the strong southerly flow. This helped to produced showers and storms across the area. The lack of instability meant most storms stayed sub severe. However, one storms was strong enough to bring down some trees, powerlines, and fencing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Manager reported large branches and fencing down around the Hampton Inn in Dade City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front pushed through west central Florida on the 18th. Increased wind shear and a strong low level jet along the cold front helped to produced showers and thunderstorms. One of those storms produced a strong marine wind gust.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet site on the Skyway Fishing Pier reported a strong marine wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong south winds gusted to between 40 and 45 mph at times in the Mississippi River counties from around Cape Girardeau north. The peak wind gust at the Cape Girardeau airport was 44 mph. The gusty south winds occurred ahead of a cold front which dropped south into the lower Ohio Valley early on the 16th.

An isolated supercell developed behind a southward sagging frontal boundary.  With around 1000 J/kg MLCAPE and 40-45 knots of effective shear, a brief supercellular structure evolved. Even with hail size somewhat limited by available instability, substantial damage to total destruction of crops occurred due to the large quantity of wind-driven hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind-driven hail produced considerable to total crop damage. Damage began around 4 miles southeast of Le Mars, and followed a nearly continuous 1 to 3 mile wide path for 17 miles to the southeast, crossing into Cherokee and Woodbury County around 6 miles east southeast of Kingsley.  Hail varied from dime to quarter size along the path, with quarter size hail 3 miles north northeast of Kingsley at 1734 CST and 5 miles east northeast of Kingsley at 1738 CST.  Winds were estimated as high as 60 to 65 mph. Damage was done to the siding of a house 1.5 miles east of O Leary at 1720 CST.  The worst crop damage occurred from 3 miles north to 4 miles east of Kingsley, where hail was still 3 inches deep on roadways an hour after the storm.  The path was determined from surface reports and Sentinel satellite data. Crop damage is an estimate from insured losses. Information provided by the United States Department of Agriculture. Property damage costs are a rough estimate.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of heavy rain moved across eastern Kentucky from late Friday, February 26th through early Monday, March 1st.  The combination of all the heavy rainfall led to significant flooding across a good portion of central and east Kentucky.  For some areas, this was the most significant flooding in the last 50 to 60 years, or more. FEMA estimates that this event cost $350-400 million dollars in damages, including both individual and public infrastructure. This is now the costliest event in Kentucky to date.||The first round of heavy rain came through on the morning of Saturday, February 27th.  This early rainfall targeted areas along the Hal Rogers Parkway, including Laurel, Clay, Perry, and Knott counties. Flash flooding let to some closed roads for a short time in these areas.  ||The second round of rainfall occurred late Saturday night as a warm front lifted northward across east Kentucky. The heavy rain stalled out over portions of Powell and Menifee Counties, leading to flash flooding into the early morning hours of Sunday.||Finally, the third round of heavy rain started late Sunday afternoon and continued through Sunday night. Given that much of the area had already received significant amounts of rain from the past two events, the ground was very saturated, and this last round caused widespread flash flooding across much of east Kentucky. As water made it's way to the larger creeks and rivers, these began to flood as well. River levels on the Kentucky river were some of the highest readings ever recorded, namely at Booneville and Ravenna. Clay City, Heidelberg, Jackson, Paintsville, and Salyersville also saw significant river flooding of which hadn't been seen in 40 to 50 years.  ||The periods of heavy rain and flooding led to numerous water rescues and mud/rock slides.  Many areas were cut off or blocked due to the flooding.  Power outages were also noted and reached as high as 12,000 during the peak of the flash flooding Sunday night.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of KY Highways 577 and 3630 are covered by high water.

The heavy rain stalled out over portions of Powell and Menifee Counties, leading to flash flooding into the early morning hours of Sunday.||Finally, the third round of heavy rain started late Sunday afternoon and continued through Sunday night. Given that much of the area had already received significant amounts of rain from the past two events, the ground was very saturated, and this last round caused widespread flash flooding across much of east Kentucky. As water made it's way to the larger creeks and rivers, these began to flood as well. River levels on the Kentucky river were some of the highest readings ever recorded, namely at Booneville and Ravenna. Clay City, Heidelberg, Jackson, Paintsville, and Salyersville also saw significant river flooding of which hadn't been seen in 40 to 50 years.  ||The periods of heavy rain and flooding led to numerous water rescues and mud/rock slides.  Many areas were cut off or blocked due to the flooding.  Power outages were also noted and reached as high as 12,000 during the peak of the flash flooding Sunday night.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 122 is blocked due to high water across the road along Bucks Branch (creek).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of heavy rain moved across eastern Kentucky from late Friday, February 26th through early Monday, March 1st.  The combination of all the heavy rainfall led to significant flooding across a good portion of central and east Kentucky.  For some areas, this was the most significant flooding in the last 50 to 60 years, or more. FEMA estimates that this event cost $350-400 million dollars in damages, including both individual and public infrastructure. This is now the costliest event in Kentucky to date.||The first round of heavy rain came through on the morning of Saturday, February 27th.  This early rainfall targeted areas along the Hal Rogers Parkway, including Laurel, Clay, Perry, and Knott counties. As water made it's way to the larger creeks and rivers, these began to flood as well. River levels on the Kentucky river were some of the highest readings ever recorded, namely at Booneville and Ravenna. Clay City, Heidelberg, Jackson, Paintsville, and Salyersville also saw significant river flooding of which hadn't been seen in 40 to 50 years.  ||The periods of heavy rain and flooding led to numerous water rescues and mud/rock slides.  Many areas were cut off or blocked due to the flooding.  Power outages were also noted and reached as high as 12,000 during the peak of the flash flooding Sunday night.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KY-979 is blocked due to high water across the road near the Mud Creek Clinic just south of Grethel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Persistent thunderstorms with heavy rain rates led to heavy rainfall and serious flooding in Osborne County during the early morning hours of May 16th. Highest rainfall totals included 8.16 from 1 WNW Codell, mainly between 1-4 AM CDT, 4.19 from 1 S Plainville, 4.11 from 13 SW of Tipton. The axis of heaviest rainfall occurred at the head of and alongside the Paradise Creek, which ultimately led to serious flash flooding of Natoma, Kansas in extreme SW Osborne County. The mayor stated that approximately 120 homes had moderate to severe damage, with another 15 likely a total loss. Approximately 22 businesses had water damage. Many people were displaced and had to be rescued from their homes. Comparisons were made to the flash flood event in 1993.||The upper level pattern consisted of diffluent and active zonal to southwest flow, with strong divergence noted in the right entrance region of 90kt 300mb jet streak running from the northern Plains into the Ohio River Valley. A strong 35-45kt low level jet developed during the late evening of the 15th and continued into the early morning hours of the 16th, with strong convergence noted on the nose of the low level jet over central and northern Kansas. The strong low level convergence, coupled with the strong upper level divergence promoted deep lift through the atmospheric column, amidst precipitable water values that peaked near 1.5, which caused heavy rain rates. In addition, thunderstorms trained over the Paradise Creek basin particularly frequently, further promoting heavy rainfall amounts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The ninth named storm, fourth hurricane, and second major hurricane of the 2021 Atlantic hurricane season, Ida originated from a tropical wave in the Caribbean Sea on August 23rd. On August 26th, the wave developed into a tropical depression, which organized further and became Tropical Storm Ida later that day, near Grand Cayman. On a northwestward track, Ida intensified into a hurricane on August 27, just before moving over western Cuba. A day later, the hurricane underwent rapid intensification over the Gulf of Mexico as it passed over a warm core eddy and reached major hurricane strength. It was just under 72 hours from tropical depression formation to category 4 strength with 150 mph winds. Ida remained at its peak intensity of 150 mph winds and a minimum central pressure of 929 millibars as it made landfall near Port Fourchon midday on August 29th. It didnt weaken to a tropical storm until it reached near the Louisiana/Mississippi border.||Ida produced over a dozen tornadoes and light to moderate wind damage across southwestern and coastal Mississippi. Around 100,000 residents were without power. Around 100 homes were damaged, 6 destroyed. Storm surge inundation ranged from a few feet in Jackson County to 7 feet in Harrison County. Hurricane Ida caused approximately $10 million worth of damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A waterspout moved onshore near Railroad St and Henderson Ave where it caused minor roof damage to several houses. The most significant damage occurred near Witman Ave where a house sustained extensive roof damage and numerous trees were snapped or uprooted. The tornado tracked to the northwest, causing additional minor roof damage and snapped trees near Blue Lake Cove. It continued to move northwest where a roof was damaged near Prentiss Rd and Hillcrest Drive. Estimated peak winds of 90 mph.

FEMA estimates that this event cost $350-400 million dollars in damages, including both individual and public infrastructure. This is now the costliest event in Kentucky to date.||The first round of heavy rain came through on the morning of Saturday, February 27th.  This early rainfall targeted areas along the Hal Rogers Parkway, including Laurel, Clay, Perry, and Knott counties. Flash flooding let to some closed roads for a short time in these areas.  ||The second round of rainfall occurred late Saturday night as a warm front lifted northward across east Kentucky. The heavy rain stalled out over portions of Powell and Menifee Counties, leading to flash flooding into the early morning hours of Sunday.||Finally, the third round of heavy rain started late Sunday afternoon and continued through Sunday night. Given that much of the area had already received significant amounts of rain from the past two events, the ground was very saturated, and this last round caused widespread flash flooding across much of east Kentucky. As water made it's way to the larger creeks and rivers, these began to flood as well. River levels on the Kentucky river were some of the highest readings ever recorded, namely at Booneville and Ravenna. Clay City, Heidelberg, Jackson, Paintsville, and Salyersville also saw significant river flooding of which hadn't been seen in 40 to 50 years.  ||The periods of heavy rain and flooding led to numerous water rescues and mud/rock slides.  Many areas were cut off or blocked due to the flooding.  Power outages were also noted and reached as high as 12,000 during the peak of the flash flooding Sunday night.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KY Highway 468 in and around the Hatfield community is covered by water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong south winds gusted to between 40 and 45 mph at times in the Mississippi River counties from around Cape Girardeau north. The peak wind gust at the Cape Girardeau airport was 44 mph. The gusty south winds occurred ahead of a cold front which dropped south into the lower Ohio Valley early on the 16th.

Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of Wednesday, July 14.  Some of the storms produced damaging winds and numerous tornadoes.  Brief torrential rainfall was also observed with the stronger storm cells.  The areas that were hit hardest were in Buchanan, Delaware, Benton, Linn, and Jones counties in IA, where a total of 14 tornadoes occurred.  7 of the tornadoes had no visible damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF-1 tornado briefly touched down on the southwest side of town damaging several farm outbuildings and a large show barn. No injuries were reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brief touchdown in a field with no visible damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tropical wave meandered in the Bay of Campeche for a few days in mid June before slowly tracking northeastward towards the Louisiana coastline. It actually didn't attain tropical storm status until after it made landfall in Terrebonne Parish on the early morning of June 19th. The generally weaker nature of the storm meant that wind and surge were the lesser of impacts. However, a band of very heavy rainfall developed on the east side of the storm and brought several inches to upwards of one foot of rain to the Mississippi coastal Counties. Peak wind gusts across the region barely reached tropical storm strength.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several buildings in Camille Village Apartments sustained minor damage to the siding and front awnings. Two buildings had their AC units blown over. One of the AC units was not found. An awning attached to the front of one of these building was completely destroyed. The roofing and awning material was lofted and found about 1,000 yards to the northwest past a fence and area of trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Pockets of minor flooding occurred following a heavy rainfall event. Rainfall rates increased the night of the 17th into early on the 18th as a mid level shortwave trough pushed southeastward into the Plains states and interacted with a warm front lifting|northward across the Ohio River Valley. A southwesterly 850 mb low level jet ramped up to 40 to 45 knots, and precipitable water values were very high for this time of year. General rainfall amounts averaged 2 to 3 inches in 24 hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A couple of lesser travelled roads were closed in flood-prone areas. Kentucky 1949 was closed at the tunnel under Interstate 69. Kentucky 1462 was closed at the Clarks River flood plain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong south winds gusted to between 40 and 45 mph at times in the Mississippi River counties from around Cape Girardeau north. The peak wind gust at the Cape Girardeau airport was 44 mph. The gusty south winds occurred ahead of a cold front which dropped south into the lower Ohio Valley early on the 16th.

With an area of high pressure centered over the Four Corners region, persistent northeasterly flow combined with sufficient low-level moisture supported another active monsoon day across northern and central New Mexico. Thunderstorm activity initiated over the northern high terrain by early afternoon, and thunderstorms intensified as the afternoon progressed as they tracked in a general southeasterly direction. One particular thunderstorm near Picuris Pueblo in Taos County produced as estimated 1.5 to 4 inches of rainfall within about three hours. This resulted in flash flooding within the area that caused significant damage to structures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 1.5 to 4 inches of heavy rainfall over the course of 3 hours resulted in flash flooding across the historic Picuris Pueblo. As water over topped an arroyo, flood waters rapidly entered the tribal administration building which sustained damages to the flooring. A gym, senior center, and transportation building were also hit hard by the flood waters which also all sustained various amounts of floor damage. Several grave markers in the tribal cemetery were dislodged by the flood waters. Damages to a hydrologic weir that feeds the fish hatchery pond, which houses about 5,000 fish, were also reported. No injuries or fatalities were reported, and damages are estimated.

CZ_NAME: WILMETTE HARBOR TO NORTHERLY ISLAND IL

Many areas were cut off or blocked due to the flooding.  Power outages were also noted and reached as high as 12,000 during the peak of the flash flooding Sunday night.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KY-30 east is closed between mile marker 11 and 13 just outside of Booneville due to high water across the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of heavy rain moved across eastern Kentucky from late Friday, February 26th through early Monday, March 1st.  The combination of all the heavy rainfall led to significant flooding across a good portion of central and east Kentucky.  For some areas, this was the most significant flooding in the last 50 to 60 years, or more. FEMA estimates that this event cost $350-400 million dollars in damages, including both individual and public infrastructure. This is now the costliest event in Kentucky to date.||The first round of heavy rain came through on the morning of Saturday, February 27th.  This early rainfall targeted areas along the Hal Rogers Parkway, including Laurel, Clay, Perry, and Knott counties. Flash flooding let to some closed roads for a short time in these areas.  ||The second round of rainfall occurred late Saturday night as a warm front lifted northward across east Kentucky. The heavy rain stalled out over portions of Powell and Menifee Counties, leading to flash flooding into the early morning hours of Sunday.||Finally, the third round of heavy rain started late Sunday afternoon and continued through Sunday night. Given that much of the area had already received significant amounts of rain from the past two events, the ground was very saturated, and this last round caused widespread flash flooding across much of east Kentucky. As water made it's way to the larger creeks and rivers, these began to flood as well. River levels on the Kentucky river were some of the highest readings ever recorded, namely at Booneville and Ravenna. Clay City, Heidelberg, Jackson, Paintsville, and Salyersville also saw significant river flooding of which hadn't been seen in 40 to 50 years.  ||The periods of heavy rain and flooding led to numerous water rescues and mud/rock slides.  Many areas were cut off or blocked due to the flooding.  Power outages were also noted and reached as high as 12,000 during the peak of the flash flooding Sunday night.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KY-715 is closed between mile markers 0 and 1 due to high water on the road near Red River Gorge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of Wednesday, July 14.  Some of the storms produced damaging winds and numerous tornadoes.  Brief torrential rainfall was also observed with the stronger storm cells.  The areas that were hit hardest were in Buchanan, Delaware, Benton, Linn, and Jones counties in IA, where a total of 14 tornadoes occurred.  7 of the tornadoes had no visible damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF-1 tornado tracked across rural Jones county snapping trees and ending just south of Canton.

Flash flooding let to some closed roads for a short time in these areas.  ||The second round of rainfall occurred late Saturday night as a warm front lifted northward across east Kentucky. The heavy rain stalled out over portions of Powell and Menifee Counties, leading to flash flooding into the early morning hours of Sunday.||Finally, the third round of heavy rain started late Sunday afternoon and continued through Sunday night. Given that much of the area had already received significant amounts of rain from the past two events, the ground was very saturated, and this last round caused widespread flash flooding across much of east Kentucky. As water made it's way to the larger creeks and rivers, these began to flood as well. River levels on the Kentucky river were some of the highest readings ever recorded, namely at Booneville and Ravenna. Clay City, Heidelberg, Jackson, Paintsville, and Salyersville also saw significant river flooding of which hadn't been seen in 40 to 50 years.  ||The periods of heavy rain and flooding led to numerous water rescues and mud/rock slides.  Many areas were cut off or blocked due to the flooding.  Power outages were also noted and reached as high as 12,000 during the peak of the flash flooding Sunday night.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: All 3 lanes of US-460 are blocked at mile marker 22 due to a mudslide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over California resulted in very hot daytime temperatures and warm overnight low temperatures across interior Northern California. High to very high heat risk impacted the region. Two daily high temperature records were broken. During the event, cooling centers were made available to the public across interior Northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sacramento region saw high temperatures reach 105 degrees. On the 14th, downtown Sacramento recorded a high temperature of 103 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over California resulted in very hot daytime temperatures and warm overnight low temperatures across interior Northern California. High to very high heat risk impacted the region. Two daily high temperature records were broken. During the event, cooling centers were made available to the public across interior Northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Motherlode region saw high temperatures reach upwards of 100 degrees during the event. A temperature of 104 degrees was reported near Placerville, CA.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over California resulted in very hot daytime temperatures and warm overnight low temperatures across interior Northern California. High to very high heat risk impacted the region. Two daily high temperature records were broken. During the event, cooling centers were made available to the public across interior Northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Northern San Joaquin Valley saw high temperatures reach over 100 degrees during the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level shortwave system which dropped southeast through the Great Basin on December 31 produced increased surface pressure gradients which resulted in strong downslope winds along the Mojave Desert slopes of the Tehachapi Mountains during the afternoon and evening hours.  Several stations measured wind gusts exceeding 45 mph with a few stations reporting gusts exceeding 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Southern California Edison station at Little Oak Canyon measured a peak wind gust of 63 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A southward moving cold front stalled across northern New Jersey and northeast Pennsylvania early on September 13. Warm and humid conditions were present south of the front. An upper level disturbance moving through the westerly flow aloft helped to increase wind shear. Combined with the instability, this disturbance caused a line of thunderstorms to move through the region during the evening hours of September 13. This line of storms became severe, with a number of reports of damaging wind along it. The line moved offshore and out of the region later that evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Valley Rd in Bernards Twp was closed between Lurline Dr and Essex Pl due to a tree and wires down. Time estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A southward moving cold front stalled across northern New Jersey and northeast Pennsylvania early on September 13. Warm and humid conditions were present south of the front. An upper level disturbance moving through the westerly flow aloft helped to increase wind shear. Combined with the instability, this disturbance caused a line of thunderstorms to move through the region during the evening hours of September 13. This line of storms became severe, with a number of reports of damaging wind along it. The line moved offshore and out of the region later that evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An mPing report of tree limbs down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of Wednesday, July 14.  Some of the storms produced damaging winds and numerous tornadoes.  Brief torrential rainfall was also observed with the stronger storm cells.  The areas that were hit hardest were in Buchanan, Delaware, Benton, Linn, and Jones counties in IA, where a total of 14 tornadoes occurred.  7 of the tornadoes had no visible damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF-1 tornado touched down southwest of Monticello damaging outbuildings and snapping large trees on two farmsteads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours in a warm and unstable air mass.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed onto Roush Hill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few showers and thunderstorms developed over eastern Pennsylvania on September 28 ahead of a cold front. Activity was isolated in nature and produced little impact overall. One storm in southeast Pennsylvania briefly became severe, before activity continued to weaken as it moved off to the east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Shingles were blown off a roof and minor tree damage occurred in Upper Chichester Twp. Time estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to eastern Pennsylvania on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the southeastern part of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Warner Road was closed at PA Route 715 in Pocono Township due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to eastern Pennsylvania on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the southeastern part of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in Berks County with many road closures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought strong (both thunderstorm, and non-thunderstorm) winds, tornadoes, dust, snow, and record temperatures into eastern Nebraska and western Iowa. The event was determined to be a derecho meeting the criteria of wind damage extending more than 250 miles, including wind gusts of at least 58 mph and numerous gusts of at least 75 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported a peak measured wind gust of 81 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Patches of dense fog formed into the early morning of September 5th around the San Francisco Bay Area and down to Monterey. Observations ranged from 1/8 of a mile to 2 miles in affected areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Napa County Airport ASOS reported visibility down to a quarter mile on and off during this time period. Weather sensor also reported fog.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Patches of dense fog formed into the early morning of September 5th around the San Francisco Bay Area and down to Monterey. Observations ranged from 1/8 of a mile to 2 miles in affected areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Santa Cruz AWOS station reported visibility down to a quarter of a mile.

CZ_NAME: SOUTHERN MONTEREY BAY AND BIG SUR COAST
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Patches of dense fog formed into the early morning of September 5th around the San Francisco Bay Area and down to Monterey. Observations ranged from 1/8 of a mile to 2 miles in affected areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Monterey Airport ASOS reported visibility down to a quarter of a mile.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and early evening hours in a warm and humid airmass that was in place across the Ohio Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A very brief and weak tornado touched down near Ribolt, just south of the AA Highway during the evening. Much of the damage was concentrated along the beginning of May Hallow Road. One tree was knocked down and several large limbs were also blown over and placed a few hundred feet from the tree. An outbuilding also sustained damage, which included partial roof collapse. Several eyewitnesses reported a funnel, and video taken near the location of damage shows a funnel extending downward near the ground. Based on an evaluation of the damage, winds associated with this brief tornado were around 65 mph.

CZ_NAME: MOUNTAINS SOUTHWESTERN SHASTA COUNTY TO WESTERN COLUSA COUNTY

During the event, cooling centers were made available to the public across interior Northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The western foothills of the Sacramento Valley saw high temperatures reach upwards of 113 degrees during the event.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Northern Sacramento Valley saw high temperatures reach in excess of 111 degrees. Two daily high temperature records were set on the 15th with Redding airport reaching 116 degrees and Red Bluff Airport reaching 112 degrees during the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over California resulted in very hot daytime temperatures and warm overnight low temperatures across interior Northern California. High to very high heat risk impacted the region. Two daily high temperature records were broken. During the event, cooling centers were made available to the public across interior Northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Central Sacramento Valley region saw high temperatures reach in excess of 109 degrees during the event. On August 14th, Marysville recorded a high temperature of 103 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The large upper high pressure center over the Great Basin not only provided much of the area with near record heat, but also spread some tropical moisture into the area on September 9 which resulted in scattered thunderstorms during the afternoon.  Moderate to heavy rainfall occured with some of the thunderstorms in the Kern County Deserts and along the Kern River Valley where several stations measured over half an inch of rainfall.  Between a quarter and a half inch of rainfell in portions of the south end of the Upper Sierra.  The rainfall was less significant elsewhere with most stations picking up betweeen a trace to a tenth of an inch of rainfall.  A few of the thunderstorms also produced strong outflow wind gusts in the Kern County Deserts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at Edwards AFB measured 1.20 inches of rainfall from a thunderstorm between 1401 PDT and 1657 PDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wet, unsettled weather pattern continued over the area with a surface front across central in the morning that lifted north into the afternoon as a warm front as a surface low developed along the boundary in the eastern GOMEX and approached Apalachee Bay. Rainfall and isolated thunderstorms continued across NE FL near the lingering surface front in the morning, then as the front retreated northward toward I-10 into the afternoon, the potential for thunderstorms across NE FL expanded northward |within the warm sector. There was a window for severe storm potential in the afternoon across NE FL where enough instability (1000-1500 J/kg MLCAPE) phased with a 35-40 kt 850 mb jet under about 40-50 kts bulk shear with HREF with STP guidance near 1-1.3  units. These ingredients favor strong wind gust potential in |isolated severe storms during this time frame (40-60 mph gusts) and a low threat of isolated, brief tornadoes with Effective SRH |200 m2/s2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to a half of a foot of standing water was reported across County Road 65.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cross country storm system, responsible for heavy snows in Seattle, snow, ice and report cold in the southern Plains and the Tennessee valley moved into New England during the overnight hours of February 15-16th. ||Snow overspread Vermont around midnight on the 16th, mixing with sleet and freezing rain before sunrise and ending by mid-morning. Combined snow and sleet accumulations were generally 3 to 6 inches with minimal icing from freezing rain. However, many roads were treacherous due to the wintry mix and many schools cancelled classes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall reports of 3 to 5 inches were common along with a light accumulation of sleet and freezing rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front across central Florida on 2/6 lifted northward as a surface low developed along the front in the eastern Gulf of Mexico. The warm front progressed northward to just south of the I-10 corridor during the night 2/6 into the early morning hours of 2/7 as the surface low track east along the front and then offshore of the local Atlantic coast early in the morning 2/7. Very strong shear was in place across the area with elevated instability with aloft with mid level lapse rates 7-7.5 deg C/km.  Some wind damage with gusts of 40-50 mph was reported as well as hail as large as quarter size. Widespread rainfall of 2-4 inches occurred in a couple of swaths across NE FL within 24 hrs which produced some localized flooding.  Most storm damage occurred in NE FL, but a rouge storm in SE GA did produce hail due to the elevated instability and high shear.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported.

CZ_NAME: FERNANDINA BEACH TO ST AUGUSTINE FL OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A SW-NE oriented line of showers associated with a prefrontal trough tracked east-southeastward across the area with isolated embedded strong storms with plenty of low level shear but limited instability in place.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A WeatherFlow mesonet site near Huguenot Park measured a wind gust to 55 mph.

CZ_NAME: FERNANDINA BEACH TO ST AUGUSTINE FL OUT 20NM

Widespread rainfall of 2-4 inches occurred in a couple of swaths across NE FL within 24 hrs which produced some localized flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The AWOS station at the St. Augustine airport measured a wind gust to 45 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several morning storms developed in the vicinity of a warm front lifting northward into south Georgia. Upper level shear increased in the hail growth zone in the morning ahead of an approaching upper level short wave trough, which resulted in several storms that produced hail 0.25-0.88 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail and about 1.5 inches of rainfall was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of strong to severe storms developed after 2 pm across NE Florida near and trailing the lifting warm front over an unstable and highly sheared air-mass. These storms expanded in coverage and intensity through 6 pm as they tracked ENE. The combination of high temperatures in the low 80s with dew pts in the upper 60s to low 70s, created high surface based CAPE near 2k J/kg with 40-50 kts of bulk shear. Hail, strong winds and isolated tornadoes impacted the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golf ball size hail was observed in Lake City. The time of the event was based on radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough dived south which helped to move a stalled out boundary over north Florida through the state. As it did the front produced strong thunderstorms and marine wind gust.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two homes received minor to moderate roof damage. Multiple trees and powerlines down between Chiefland and Fanning Springs.

CZ_NAME: ENGLEWOOD TO TARPON SPRINGS FL OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Short waves moving along a stationary boundary just north of I-4 produced strong marine thunderstorm winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station on Clearwater Beach reported a strong marine winds gust.

CZ_NAME: TARPON SPRINGS TO SUWANNEE RIVER FL OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Short waves moving along a stationary boundary just north of I-4 produced strong marine thunderstorm winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station near Cedar Key reported a strong marine wind gust.

CZ_NAME: TARPON SPRINGS TO SUWANNEE RIVER FL OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line that formed ahead of a strong cold front pushes through the Gulf of Mexico bringing strong marine wind gust.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Buoy off of Cedar Key produced a strong wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line that formed ahead of a strong cold front pushes through the Gulf of Mexico bringing strong marine wind gust.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: AWOS at MacDill AFB reported a strong marine wind gust.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornadic storm developed in a discrete supercell in advance of an approaching cold front and south of  a lifting warm front. The tornado impacted areas east of Lake Wilson. Sporadic wind damage including damaged trees, fences, roofs and some other residential home damage occurred. Tree debris was strewn throughout the tornado path. Roof damage included that done to tile roofs near High Point Drive. A fence panel was blown about 750 ft from its original location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of strong to severe storms developed after 2 pm across NE Florida near and trailing the lifting warm front over an unstable and highly sheared air-mass. These storms expanded in coverage and intensity through 6 pm as they tracked ENE. The combination of high temperatures in the low 80s with dew pts in the upper 60s to low 70s, created high surface based CAPE near 2k J/kg with 40-50 kts of bulk shear. Hail, strong winds and isolated tornadoes impacted the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A barn was blown down along Pinemount Road. The time of damage was based on radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of strong to severe storms developed after 2 pm across NE Florida near and trailing the lifting warm front over an unstable and highly sheared air-mass. These storms expanded in coverage and intensity through 6 pm as they tracked ENE. The combination of high temperatures in the low 80s with dew pts in the upper 60s to low 70s, created high surface based CAPE near 2k J/kg with 40-50 kts of bulk shear. Hail, strong winds and isolated tornadoes impacted the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A couple of structures had roof damage. Some fencing was blown through the window of a home. The time of damage was based on radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wet, unsettled weather pattern continued over the area with a surface front across central in the morning that lifted north into the afternoon as a warm front as a surface low developed along the boundary in the eastern GOMEX and approached Apalachee Bay. Rainfall and isolated thunderstorms continued across NE FL near the lingering surface front in the morning, then as the front retreated northward toward I-10 into the afternoon, the potential for thunderstorms across NE FL expanded northward |within the warm sector. There was a window for severe storm potential in the afternoon across NE FL where enough instability (1000-1500 J/kg MLCAPE) phased with a 35-40 kt 850 mb jet under about 40-50 kts bulk shear with HREF with STP guidance near 1-1.3  units. These ingredients favor strong wind gust potential in |isolated severe storms during this time frame (40-60 mph gusts) and a low threat of isolated, brief tornadoes with Effective SRH |200 m2/s2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A rain wrapped funnel cloud was reported near State Road 13A.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The exceptional (D4) and extreme (D3) drought categories continued across a large part of southeast Arizona during January, with the exception of western Pima County. Precipitation totals for the month totaled 0.5 to 1.5 inches, with higher amounts in the form of snow on the highest mountains. These totals were 25 to 125 percent of normal, but even where substantial precipitation occurred, were not enough to improve the drought status. Soil moisture readings improved slightly, but were still below the 5th percentile ranking across Santa Cruz and eastern sections of Pima and Pinal counties and below the 10th percentile ranking elsewhere. Levels at San Carlos Reservoir remained around 2 percent of storage capacity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The exceptional (D4) and extreme (D3) drought categories continued across a large part of southeast Arizona during January, with the exception of western Pima County. Precipitation totals for the month totaled 0.5 to 1.5 inches, with higher amounts in the form of snow on the highest mountains. These totals were 25 to 125 percent of normal, but even where substantial precipitation occurred, were not enough to improve the drought status. Soil moisture readings improved slightly, but were still below the 5th percentile ranking across Santa Cruz and eastern sections of Pima and Pinal counties and below the 10th percentile ranking elsewhere. Levels at San Carlos Reservoir remained around 2 percent of storage capacity.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wet August continued into early September and ended the extreme (D3) drought category designation in far southeast Cochise County early in the month.  This marked the first time since August 2020 that the drought category was severe (D2) or lower across all of southeast Arizona.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wet August continued into early September and ended the extreme (D3) drought category designation in far southeast Cochise County early in the month.  This marked the first time since August 2020 that the drought category was severe (D2) or lower across all of southeast Arizona.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few late afternoon showers formed in the moisture left over from the remnants of tropical system Nora. While no lightning was detected, a funnel cloud was observed near Sonoita.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A short-lived funnel cloud was reported and captured on video near Sonoita.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed and moved southwest across southeast Arizona during the afternoon and early evening hours. Thunderstorm winds produced considerable damage in Safford. Sporadic wind and lightning damage also occurred the greater Tucson Metro Area.

Scattered thunderstorms developed and moved southwest across southeast Arizona during the afternoon and early evening hours. Thunderstorm winds produced considerable damage in Safford. Sporadic wind and lightning damage also occurred the greater Tucson Metro Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearly 1.5 of rain in about 30 minutes caused flash flooding of streets in Safford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed and moved southwest across southeast Arizona during the afternoon and early evening hours. Thunderstorm winds produced considerable damage in Safford. Sporadic wind and lightning damage also occurred the greater Tucson Metro Area.

A potent storm system affected Central Alabama on Thursday, March 25th. A highly-sheared environment combined with increasing instability produced numerous tornadic thunderstorms. Severe parameters were supportive of significant and long-track supercells, prompting the issuance of a rare High Risk Convective Outlook from the Storm Prediction Center for portions of Central Alabama.||A total of 10 tornado tracks were surveyed in Central Alabama. This included 4 EF3 tornadoes, 3 EF2 tornadoes, and 3 EF1 tornadoes. Damage was significant along the paths of the most intense tornadoes and, unfortunately, injuries and fatalities occurred. |Some storms were cyclic, meaning multiple tornadoes were produced by the same storm. The most impressive tornado of the event was the long-track tornado that traveled nearly 80 miles from Hale County to Shelby County. This ranked as the seventh longest single tornado track in the state of Alabama.

Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to New Jersey on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the northern half of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NJ Route 73 in Palmyra was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought strong (both thunderstorm, and non-thunderstorm) winds, tornadoes, dust, snow, and record temperatures into eastern Nebraska and western Iowa. The event was determined to be a derecho meeting the criteria of wind damage extending more than 250 miles, including wind gusts of at least 58 mph and numerous gusts of at least 75 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public report via mping of 3-inch tree limbs broken; power poles broken.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although rainfall was above normal for December, nearly all of the central California Interior was classified as being in a moderate to severe drought at the end of December, 2021 due to a long term precipitation deficit. As of December 31, 2021, most of the impacted area has received less than 60% of normal precipitation since July 1, 2020.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sequoia National Park was classified as being in a severe drought due to a long term precipitation deficit.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front helped kick off a round of thunderstorms the afternoon of Sunday May 9. Wind damage and large hail accompanied a few of these storms across parts of Central Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A public report indicated quarter sized hail near the city of West, TX.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Though a cold front had already pushed through the area, a strong upper level disturbance led to the development of strong and severe thunderstorms on Monday May 10 in the cool sector north of the front. Large hail occurred in several locations mainly along and north of the Interstate 20 corridor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fire and Rescue reported half-dollar sized hail in Stephenville, TX.
